Andy Serkis gets top billing in Dawn of the Planet of the Apes and not without good reason. It's possible that without his performance the movie might have been just another forgettable, big-budget Hollywood special effects prequel, but he makes the movie come alive in a way that from now on, he should no longer be dismissed as just "that CG guy." After playing Gollum in The Lord of the Rings, and the big ape in King Kong he has cemented himself as the king of The Uncanny Valley.

Serkis' performance brings unexpected levels of emotion and conflict out of a character created out of computer generated imagery. Caesar is an ape of very few words, but his face speaks volumes. It's an effect so beautifully done that after a while you stop trying to see the visual effect and start feeling for the character.

The performance builds on what Serkis created three years ago in 2011's Rise of the Planet of the Apes. When we met Caesar then, he was a lab monkey burning with distrust for the Homo sapiens who had caged him up in a science lab and fed him a drug to give him human intelligence. Now, 10 years later, he has grown more mature and more brooding and more thoughtful.

The story picks up 10 years after the previous film, the virus called "Simian Flu" has decimated most of the world's human population. Man has withered down to the bare bones, while the ape society has flourished in the Muir Woods outside of San Francisco. We see Caesar as the leader of the now tribal apes who have developed a primitive society not too far removed from those at the opening of 2001: A Space Odyssey.

There is a dividing line, however. While the apes have evolved, there is a tense but festering hatred between the ape world and the human world. Both are on tenterhooks with each other. Man lives in the ruins of the cities while ape makes his home in the woods. The drama kicks off when the humans (who live in what is left of San Francisco) discover that their supplies are depleting and the only way to keep from running out is to start up the nearby hydroelectric dam - which unfortunately is deep inside ape territory.

Misunderstanding begets misunderstanding. Man goofs up, and the ape's mistrust grows until - horror of horrors - they discover that man has a stockpile of guns. That only scratches the surface. There's a lot of plot in this movie, a lot of story threads to work out but the story isn't the most interesting element. The best thing about Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is the level of tension that director Matt Reeves is able to maintain. The earlier scenes are the best as we can clearly feel the lines drawn between the two sides and also the conflict in Caesar's soul as he questions his moral values. He finds himself at odds with his second-in-command, a nasty ape named Koba who is prepped for a violent conflict. The apes all seem like individuals, and despite the fact that most of them look alike, you can tell them apart.

Those are the good points. This is a problematic film in many ways. It's too long; the message is repeated over and over; the dialogue is perfunctory, and the narrative moves uneasily back and forth between ominous dread and emotional leanings. It's an uneasy mixture that leads to an ending that is bittersweet when it should be knocking our socks off. The great tradition of The Planet of the Apes movies going all the way back to the 1968 original is that they always end with a punch in a gut. This one closes on a note that tries to be emotional and the result is painfully awkward. Director Reeves wants to have it both ways with the emotional and the suspenseful but he has trouble juggling both at the same time. The movie is a jumbled mix of elements that work meshed with elements that do not. It's a good movie that leaves you wishing for something a little more surefooted.

Rise of the Planet of the Apes was such a surprise to me back in 2011.  It was a fun and entertaining movie that still had the emotional undertones to carry the movie through even if they weren't always deep.  And that's where the problems for me for Dawn of the Planet of the Apes begins.  New director, new cast, and the darker focus all just makes it seem so unrelated.  I have been a huge proponent in the past of the gritty film genre, but here the setting is so bleak, you wonder why it even was billed as a summer blockbuster.  I can't quite figure out still if Malcolm is the best or worst part of the movie.  He and his family are really the viewer, they don't do much (since it is Caesar's movie) but the emotional relationship with Caesar is what shines.  I feel it has a lot of ups and downs.  Like clearly if Oldman's plan to blow up a tower to eliminate all apes were to work, why did like 90% of them survive, and he clearly knew that if the military were to come after.  I'll watch part 3, but I hope next time it isn't dreck to watch and the film remembers there is still some fun even if it wants to be moody.

Because we've seen the original film series we know that the apes will prevail and eventually the humans will be reduced to servitude but this is an intelligent reinterpretation of the original theme and the story telling and action are impressive. I'm not sure exactly how the performances from the apes was achieved, obviously partly CGI and real acting but the result is that the "apes" turn in more impressive performances than the humans. A sequel which is as good as, if not better then the previous film, is a rarity, but here we are treated to this rare phenomenon , enjoy.

A follow-up to 2011's reboot of a storied franchise, 'Dawn of the Planet of the Apes' takes a look at what would happen to society if a deadly virus wiped out nearly the entire human race, leaving an overgrown wasteland that is ripe for the taking by another species. As is the case in the aforementioned 'Rise of the Planet of the Apes,' the film takes place in San Francisco, and things kick off when a band of human survivors stumble upon a thriving colony of apes, led by none other than Caesar (Andy Serkis). The crux of the matter is, the human who've taken refuge in San Francisco want to reconfigure an old hydroelectric dam in order to restore power to the ruined city. As one might expect, this is easier said than done.

There are a great deal of things to like about 'Dawn.' For one, the animation of the apes is top-notch, as they almost appear as lifelike as the humans they star alongside. Additionally, the language invented for the apes is intricate and intelligently designed, and the constant subtitles are not off-putting in the least. On the human side of things, Jason Clarke delivers the standout performance of the film as Malcom, the fearless leader of the refugees who must keep his comrades under control when emotions run high. Gary Oldman does not disappoint, either, but Keri Russell resurfaces in a role that is not all that memorable.

While 'Dawn' is not an amazing cinematic experience, it does offer up enough high-energy scenes and keeps audiences entertained with a series of close calls and misinformation that swirls thanks to opportunists on both sides. Aside from the CGI and acting, the soundtrack that supports 'Dawn' is very fitting, and gives the film an extra boost. At 130 minutes, the runtime is not a major issue, but there are a few scenes that seem to drag on a bit.

'Dawn of the Planet of the Apes' is one of the more understated sci-fi summer blockbusters of the past few years, but it's definitely worth a watch for the CGI and action alone.

Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes
Published July 31, 2014 | By The Blue Took
- By Bryan Stumpf

 

"His glassy essence, like an angry ape, Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven, As makes the angels weep."

Measure for Measure, Shakespeare

 

"I'm very ape and very nice."

Very Ape, Nirvana

 

Was I out of my damn dirty mind? Reviewing a talking apes movie for The Slaughtered Bird, the great movie web-site dedicated to all things horror?
Yet ten minutes in, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes proves itself a murky dark chapter in the Planet of the Apes saga, with moments more horrifying than anything I've seen in 2014 horror so far. Fully loaded with rain-soaked matted fur and apes with semi-automatics, it's clear director Matt Reeves (Cloverfield, Let Me In) and writers Mark Bomback, Rick Jaffa, and Amanda Silver were gunning for a second installment à la Empire Strikes Back for the Apes prequel trilogy.

Dawn opens ten years after the simian-flu from Rise of the Planet of the Apes has decimated most of the planet's human population. Rise's super-intelligent apes have established a peaceful, sustainable civilization, deep in the Muir redwoods, north of San dotpotatFrancisco, governed by alpha ape Caesar (Andy Serkis). Then, the inevitable altercation with humans, as a scouting team ventures into the woods, seeking access to a broken down dam.

The humans, led by Malcolm - played by unlikely yet likeable leading man Jason Clarke (Lawless, Zero Dark Thirty) - explain to the apes, if they can rebuild the dam, the few hundred survivors in the city can be supplied with life-sustaining power. The shaky negotiation of human and ape territorial rights leads to alliances and betrayals within both animal groups. While Malcolm empathizes with the apes, many of the humans, including the bullhorn-toting ex-cop Dreyfus (Gary Oldman), blame the primates for the millions dead due to flu-infection. And while Caesar cautiously decides to work with the humans, his chief lieutenant Koba (Toby Kebbell) gestures to the jagged scars over his face from torturous lab testing and cites "human work."

Dawn's writers allow the characters to evolve in satisfyingly complicated ways. Your sympathies will be tested. Both humans and apes commit horrific crimes, each group seeking to etch out the new moralities in a post-pandemic nation. Further muddying the waters are huge stashes of heavy artillery, the machinery of the old world, providing a 2nd amendment-steeped allegory to the nation-building.

Hint: you'll be reminded of the opening of 2001: A Space Odyssey, when apes discover dominance through weaponry, while picking through discarded bones.
J.J. Abrams disciple Reeves secures dominance as a director with deeply resonant scenes of apes standing atop rusting San Francisco cable cars and angry ape Koba perched, looming above a tattered Old Glory. With cinematographer Michael Seresin, Reeves choreographs impressive, sweeping action sequences - you won't forget the lengthy single shot with the camera firmly mounted to a renegade tank's turret. Reeves keeps the intensity pitched high, allowing for moments more shocking and disturbing than anything you'd find in typical summer movie fare. Yet with the hairy tapestry unfolding with such character-driven resonance, Dawn hews close to a nearly Shakespearean action movie.

dotpota1With Serkis' second turn as Caesar, he cements his rep as the Lawrence Olivier of mo-cap acting. Caesar's every move and facial expression exudes richly detailed subtext, clearly demarcating a breadth of inner turmoil, from justified ferocity to quiet dignity to anguished near-surrender. It's time Serkis was nominated for an Oscar. Considering Kebbell's Koba stands toe-to-toe with Serkis' Caesar, matching and sometimes exceeding Serkis in mo-cap vibrancy, he too deserves award consideration.

The ape performances so overshadow the human performances, you pity Clarke and Oldman for their boringly human roles. And yet some blame belongs to the writers. Many of the human characters are more sketched than fully written. Keri Russell and Kodi Smit-McPhee, playing Malcolm's love interest and son, respectively, aren't given much to do other than look worriedly at Malcolm. And while the digital technology of the ape army will surely wow audiences, the technical mastery unfortunately makes the few CGI hiccups more noticeable - the effects supervisors could have spent a little more time on Caesar's baby and the CGI horses.
Yet the aping Serkis and Kebbell will dominate your two hours with Dawn. And it will come as no surprise that Reeves' team has been tapped for the next Planet of the Apes sequel.

Most audiences will surely bow before Caesar, impressed by Serkis' haunting performance in Reeves' darkly intense narrative. To all movie-goers, I say brace thyself and hail Caesar!

I love the Planet of the Ape's movies, even Conquest and Battle (which I admit are a little bit terrible but I still enjoy it). I was so keen for this movie that I had to hold myself in or I would transform into an ape. So does the movie live up to my expectations? 
This movie starts with a little predictable opening scene, broken news reports on how the world has entered a post-apocalyptic situation, an aftermath of the first movie. However when the movie really starts, you are thrown right into the action. From then on the story deviates from what you expect and tells you the story you didn't know you wanted, predictable it is not. The film seamlessly blends exciting action scenes (what is more exciting than an ape riding a horse with two machine guns, name one thing, I dare you) with the underlying moral themes similar to those found in the original and this movie's predecessor. Like a good sequel it expands the story, adds many new characters while developing the characters we already loved. It also increases the action and deepens the complexity of the narrative. The CGI and special effects are all of the highest quality, filming on real sets really has shone through and added to the spectacle of the film. Every ape looks fantastic. 
There were many great actors cast as the main humans in the movie, I mean Gary Oldman alone makes anything impressive, but I am also a fan Jason Clarke. Not to mention that bald guy who looks like your typical dickhead in movies, Kodi Smit-Mcphee and Keri Russell. However, the real stars that steal the show are the apes. Toby Kebbell as Koba was absolutely fantastic, but the real outstanding performance, no surprise is Andy Serkis; Lord of motion capture. I honestly believe he could be anything he wants to be, because he surely exceeded as Caesar, just as excellent as Gollum if not better.
So did this movie live up to my expectations? It took my expectations and pounded them with its big ape fists. It was nothing I could have expected, an excellent sequel that transcends the previous film. The best part about it is that it's a planet of the Apes movie, apes are just awesome. Some small problems: I would've liked to see more of the world, I would've love to sit through a longer film, but that's just me, I would gladly watch hours of the planet of the apes and I have. I have no real problems with this movie and it is an instant favourite of mine. Very close to Phamtastic but alas no cigar.

The movie takes place many years after the events of the first movie. In it, humans and apes live separately, and are attempting to live in peace. However, friction between the two species is increasing, and war is drawing nearer. However, the humans are not as hostile as the trailers suggest that they are, and both sides could be sympathized with.

This film had amazing special effects, and an interesting story. The acting was very good. Andy Serkis, in a motion capture suit, delivers a great performance as Caesar the ape. Gary Oldman is very convincing as a leader trying to sustain the human race. Overall, this is a film that I would recommend to fans of the Planet of the Apes franchise.

There is something magical bout this film that I've been looking for a very very long time. The dramatic musical pieces timed the film very well in terms of it's dramatic and epic proportions as the story progresses. I'm telling you this will eat your hearts out as it is a very heartfelt and heartwarming film I've seen in years. This sequel is just beyond expectation as this is a must watch and a spectacular cinematic experience that movie goers and enthusiasts have been hungry for a one great film. A+ film 5 stars out of 5.

'Dawn of the Planet of the Apes' is a welcome addition the The Planet of the Apes collection of movies. Brilliant story & well shot. As the film opens, we see how the genetically engineered virus created by Gen-sys has spread killing a majority of the human population. Caesar & the apes have evolved since Rise of the Planet of the Apes. They form communities, hunt together, and recognize one leader to guide them. When the humans led by Malcolm played by Jason Clarke go on an expedition to repair a hydro power plant because they are running out of Diesel fuel, Carver gets in a confrontation with two of the Apes & shoots one in a panic. When he returns chased by the apes, Caesar and the Apes tell Malcolm & his party to leave. "Go". When Malcolm returns he tells Dreyfus (Gary Oldman) about the talking Apes, and how they have to think about what they just discovered. Caesar shows up with all his Apes as a show of force to the Human survivors encampment and tells them there will be no war as long as they stay out of the Apes territory. Malcolm tells Dreyfus he must try and repair the Power Plant and wants to take a peaceful expedition to ask Caesars permission to repair the Power Plant. Unrest as Koda does not trust or like the humans causes conflict between the Apes and Humans. As the humans repair the power plant with the help of the Apes as Ellie helps heal Caesar's wife, Koda attacks the humans. When he returns he devises a plan to get rid of Caesar, and in the process starts the War against Ape and Man. A really great film that gives real depth to Caesar and the Apes, with amazing human expression & dramatic performances that helped the film get a nomination for Best Visual Effects. See it for the story, the effects are secondary & just help you believe that the Apes are real.

Review for Dawn of the Planet of the Apes?

STORY

The story expands from 10 years after the incidents of Simian Flu. It's basically about the survival and getting back what humans lost and the up-rising of Apes. Apes are now more intelligent, tactical. I really loved the flaw of the story. Started with a adrenalin pumping sequence, then turned in to an emotional flaw then the intense and total epicness. The story had some minor issues and let the questions like what happened to the previous characters and some questionable incidents remaining. Yes, I saw how Rise Of The Planet Of The Apes ended where that Air craft pilot saw himself infected with the Simian Flu, but it would be great if they screen some more footage how the Simian Flu expanded around the globe. Based on ten year gap between the events of Rise of the Planet of the Apes and Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, 3 short movies which 20th Century Fox and Vice Media's Motherboard released. Some of the questionable things are touched by those short movies, but not enough for the general audience. Not gonna say more about the story due to spoilers. But I would strongly recommend to watch the 3 short movies which are at least touching the time gap between the end of 1st movie and this, before you go to the cinema. ( Links for the 3 short movies are below the end of the review ). Expect some awesome few twists in the movie too. 

ACTING, CHARACTERS 

Ever each actor who played  human characters did their job well. But I didn't see anything extra ordinary from the human characters except Gary Oldman, Keri Russell an Kirk Acevedo. Well it's obvious that they focused a lot about the perspective of Apes this time, which is a great thing. 

Talking about the Ape characters and the actors who played those characters, Andy Serkis stole every each scene he appeared in the movie as Caesar. He literally is the father of the motion capture CGI acting and it was an OSCAR winning performance. Andy again succeeded to portrait his character " Caesar " as a great, courageous, fearless, wise and inspirational leader just like in the prequel movie. And Koba is the 2nd most interesting character I found in the movie. At 1st, he looks like an arrogant, hot headed ape who hates humans more than anything. But he is more than meets the eye. He was a bad-ass character and Toby Kebbell ,the actor who played the character " Koba ", did a marvelous performance by acting as a stupid ape and as a wise ape. Nick Thurston played the character named " Blue Eyes " Caesar's son, did an impressive performance. Apes had lot more character in this movie. We can feel like they have their own characteristics and attitude. And need to give the credit for Terry Notary who was the movement choreographer of the Apes. Director Matt Reeves handled the characters very well and it's something amazing to see from a director who is not a veteran. And so glad and faithful that the sequel which comes in 2016 of the franchise is in his hands.

VISUAL EFFECTS, ACTION, 3D

I can undoubtedly say, this is the best CGI I saw in a live action movie so far in my life. Apes were so realistic that we can't even imagine that, those apes are not actual apes, but played by humans. The expressions of the creatures are well captured and crafted. All credit goes to VFX Supervisor Joe Letteri and his crew in Weta Digital in the Visual effects company behind all this unimaginable creation. Cinematography of the movie is mind blowing. Action sequence very well choreographed and loved the camera angles which built the intense superbly. Use of 3D could be much more better,yet the depth was solid. Not essential to watch in 3D.

In a side note, the aspect ratio of the movie is 1.85 : 1. Which is short in width than an average asset ratio of a movie ( 2.35 : 1 ). That kinda bothered me at 1st because I wanted to experience the movie in a big scale. But after few minutes , That was forgivable because,we barely notice that with the excitement and the curious we get from the movie.

SCORE

Michael Giacchino's composing was one of the best thing I experienced in the movie. The score succeeded to ignite the intense, action, emotional and adrenalin pumping sequences through-out the movie.

PROS (+) AND CONS (-)

* Some unanswered questions (-)
* Aspect ratio (-)
* Visual effects and everything else (+)

FINAL WORD

This movie is totally an ape movie which focused a lot about the perceptive of Apes yet it makes us realize, how humans become animals and animal become better than humans. And one of the greatest sequels ever made and I got almost everything I wanted to see in this sequel despite the questionable things I mentioned above. And make sure to watch the 3 short movies I mentioned about ( Links for the 3 short movies are below the end of the review ).

Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes is a visually stunning, realistic CGI included, epic and inspirational movie that will remain in your most favorite movie sequels of all time. And so far, this is my most favorite live action movie of this year.

* I also heard that the official prequel short novel by Gregory Keyes answered lot of unanswered things we notices in the movie. So If you want to be answered, do read that novel. It's available as an e-book too.

My rating 9.5/10

The war that mankind never expected has dawned on us with the brilliance of director Matt Reeves and WETA Digital Studio. A follow-up to the successful reboot of the world that apes ruled, DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES smashes the previous versions with genuine storytelling and great performances.

The first act proves to be an unusually enriching ride with an almost silent treatment focused on the ape world. Then come humans armed with fear and hope. The conflict of emotions starts to carve its mark with the warring factions aim to achieve ultimate survival. The values of trust and compassion are greatly unearthed as the plot thickens. WETA works its magic frame by frame with the visual wonders. The well-defined performances prove that Andy Serkis (Caesar) and the gang can deliver along with the digital artistry. I'm happy that Jason Clarke gets good projects. When I saw him in "Zero Dark Thirty", I knew that this guy is up for something grander.

There's more to this world in the future. Prepare to be amazed. 4.5/5 folks!

Swinging in at 2 hours, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes has a solid mixture of story, character, and action.  Things are predictable and there are times when the plot details become tedious; however, as a whole, this picture comes together.

It can be said that this picture relies heavily on CG, and yes it does.  All can be forgiven if done the right way and this film does it the right way.  The motion capture and the presentation of the apes are spectacular in their own right; almost as if they are standing right there with the rest of the actors.

The human characters serve as a good contrast to the apes, which is much welcome.  Watching 2 hours of apes just wouldn't be the same.  Jason Clarke, Gary Oldman, and Keri Russell have the major human characters to follow.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes never brings the suspense or excitement, yet it is still a recommendable piece.

As an unashamed fan of the original Planet of the Apes films (which I once picked up for under a fiver), I am more than happy to enjoy this Sequel to the Reboot of the Remake of the Planet of the Apes. What's been delivered is another entertaining film; almost, but not quite the equal of its predecessor, with a decent story and characters, and special effects at the top of their game.

This is the eighth film in a franchise rich with possibilities, which has always reflected the concerns of society, from nuclear war, slavery and segregation in the 1960s and 70s, to the 21st Century concerns of animal testing, genetic engineering, global pandemics and our relationship with the environment, always with the chilling edge that comes from displacing humanity from its comfortable position as the planet's dominant species.

As a quasi-prequel to the first Planet of the Apes (1968), we get to see this process in action as we return to the titular planet (spoiler: it's Earth!) some years after the aforementioned pandemic which appeared as the end sequence of Rise, killing 90% of the human population. With no humans seen for some time, the thought in the now thriving society led by ape liberator Caesar is that the last survivors have perished, but a chance encounter on a hunting expedition reveals the truth.

An expedition of humans has ventured deep into ape territory with the intention of restarting a hydroelectric dam to restore power to the ruins of San Francisco. With a deep mistrust of humans at the very core of ape doctrine, the plan becomes a tense diplomatic mission as the humans and apes negotiate to avoid another brutal conflict and needless loss of life.

Caesar is played by master of motion capture Andy Serkis and amazingly, the motion capture was largely filmed on location in the forests of Vancouver, the CGI seamlessly integrated with live action. As a character, Caesar is rare among apes in that he was raised by a human and can see the good in them.

Our human hero is Malcolm (Jason Clarke), a survivalist and engineer, who is in charge of the expedition, but is not much of a leader. Neither is he a diplomat, but he is level headed enough to develop a relationship with Caesar, with whom they share a common goal which transcends the interspecies squabble - each has a family they would do anything to protect.

The real leader of the humans is back in San Francisco: the militaristic but pragmatic Dreyfus (Gary Oldman) who has already lost his family (he swipes through their pictures on a prominently placed iPad - in shops now!) and has little desire to understand or relate to the apes.

The previous director Rupert Wyatt is replaced here by Matt Reeves, who gave us found footage monster movie Cloverfield, where the tantalising excitement of citywide destruction just off-screen was undermined by the idiotic decisions made by the protagonists. There are shades of this frustrating characterisation here with one member of Malcolm's team, Carver.

He is nothing more than a catalyst; right from the opening scene, where he shoots first and thinks later, wounding Caesar's son Blue Eyes in the process, everything about him screams "I'm the arsehole who's constantly going to jeopardise this fragile diplomacy" - which is barely saved from the brink of collapse more than once before the inevitable final showdown.

Koba fills this role for the apes, but he is a stronger character and an established personal rival of Caesar, who tries to corrupt the younger apes, including Cesar's impressionable young son Blue Eyes.

For fans of the older films, there are plenty of nods to the continuity. Caesar's family, his wife Cornelia and son Blue Eyes, call to mind Roddy McDowell's ape scientist Cornelius, and the nickname 'Bright Eyes' given to Charlton Heston's astronaut Taylor in the original. This is not quite the same Caesar as in Conquest and Battle, both of which are mined again for thematic material, but like the reboot of Star Trek (2011), the time-travel elements of the story are flexible enough to allow multiple canonical continuities, the seeds of which were being sown as early as Escape, and ultimately enabled the hope for reconciliation at the end of Battle.

We also remember the dramatic "No!" - The first words spoken by an ape in both Conquest and Rise, when Caesar flexes his vocal chords to deliver an ultimatum to the humans, but the apes here tend to converse in sign language amongst themselves. Perhaps they see spoken language as a hallmark of humanity, but they prefer to save their English skills to dramatically intimidate humans, reminding them that they share a level of intelligence which apes may even have surpassed with their sense of community. While the apes have built a new society from the ground up, the surviving humans continue to scavenge in the ruins of their decaying civilisation, relying on old technology.

There's a great scene about halfway through the film. Power is restored to an old petrol station in the woods, and as it flickers into life a song plays from a stereo: The Weight by The Band, a song which is both religious allegory and an exploration of the music which flows from the American South. Its thematic relevance extends to include references to Judgement Day and the American civil rights movement.

Hearing recorded music and seeing artificial light, symbolic of humanity's legacy, offers a spot of hope, which is inevitably undercut by the melancholy of the world lost and the inevitability of an impending finale, which I'm going to talk about now, so stop reading to avoid spoilers. Hey, I've already told you that they managed to get the power back on so Gary Oldman can charge his iPad.

The audience wants a fight, we've paid to see apes with machine guns, and a fight is what we get, courtesy of the hot headed Koba and unrelenting Dreyfus. Lamentably although hell inevitably breaks loose, credibility is stretched. The previously pacifist apes are far too good at using the machine guns they have only recently stolen from the humans.

We know the apes have both intelligence and physical strength on their side, but it's hard to explain hold their own so well against the trained human guards. Ultimately, they overwhelm the humans with sheer numbers, when they might have concocted a strategic assault using some kind of unique and established ape advantage, such as their non verbal communication, or climbing ability.

Still, all things considered, it's an entertaining film, but really not for those who don't subscribe to the sub-genre of 'ape films'.

Simply incredible. The score by Michael Giachinno is grand and epic with few, subtle, cues as homages to the original Planet of The Apes' soundtrack. It's gripping from beginning to end. The special effects have improved 10 fold. Not once did I think something looked fake or not real. Performances are all on par with the past movies, powerful and engaging. I think it's official that I can't get into these movies. I will admit that the story was better in Dawn of the Planet of the Apes than it was in Rise, and the CGI is getting better. However, despite the improvements, I still don't feel engaged by the plot and the CGI animals still don't feel real. I'll get to my frustration with the story, but first let's talk about the special effects in this movie. There are several moments, like early in the movie when the apes are confronted by a bear, that I just feel like I'm watching a video game with really great graphics. The slower moments are the best, in fact any time they capture an ape that is posed in one position it looks amazingly authentic, but they haven't mastered the visual effect of the movement. And there are very few scenes where I actually believe the humans and the apes are part of the same world. I won't bother going into how odd it is when you think about naked apes running around which (in order to keep the PG-13 rating) have been given the Ken-doll crotch, because frankly I'm just fine with not watching 2 hours of monkey junk flopping around. However I will say that, and you can call me an ape-ist, but they all look the same to me. Aside from the orangutan and gorilla, I really struggled at times to differentiate one ape from another. They tried to fix that by giving scars and other quirks to some of the more prominent ape characters but I still struggled, perhaps in part because I was mildly distracted and disinterested in the story.

So now that I've worked my way back to that, let's get into my issues with the story. In Dawn of the Planet of the Apes a majority of the humans have died, and the remainder are desperately fending for themselves. Meanwhile apes have begun to thrive and build their own elaborate society. What ends up happening when these 2 societies collide is that a few good-natured people on both sides (who intend to reach a mutually agreeable peace) are constantly being undermined by someone behaving like a classic mustache-twirling villain. They establish motives for the villainy, but I can't help being extremely frustrated as every good deed is met with more manufactured obstacles. The story of how war is created probably isn't all that far off from things that have gone on in the real world, but I tend to look to movies for more escapism and I don't feel like watching the frustrations of real-life politics played out for 2 hours. It's a surprisingly smart script and it certainly sets the stage for a continuing franchise that will thrive, it's just not one that I'm interested in. They do too good of a job at creating likable characters and unlikable characters on both sides of the battle, and so I just sit there and think "what is the end result I should be hoping for in this movie?" By the end I'm simply watching things happen and I've completely checked out emotionally. For fans of Rise of the Planet of the Apes, I think Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is even better. For those who aren't fans of this series, you won't find some masterpiece here that changes your opinion.

This feels like two movies to me: one half, a thoughtful meditation on interpersonal conflict mixed with the twin needs for power and safety. The other, a well executed but entirely generic and underwhelming action movie. I really can't understand what went wrong. For the first half, this is one of the most thought provoking movies I've ever seen. And then, at the exact point where the movie should have kicked it up into high gear and become the stuff of legends, it instead undoes a fantastic twist and goes out in what it must have assumed was a bang, but was more a low chortle.

The reboot of the Planet of the Apes series started off with a bang and continues with greatness in this second film.  Taking place many years after the first one, the planet is wiped out of most of the humans and the apes are all smarter and living together in their own colony.  The film focuses mainly on the apes and really humanizes them to an entire new level.  This film was packed with emotion from both the human and animal side and it all fit together fantastically with the rest of the stuff going on around it.  There was plenty of great action along with a brisk pace that rarely ever got boring. "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is a quality sequel in this rebooted series.  While the storyline and human actors fall far short of its predecessor (how can a few Australian no-names compare to James Franco and John Lithgow?), the film makes up for it with jaw-dropping visual effects.  In fact, this film might actually challenge "Interstellar" for the Best Visual Effects Oscar.  "Dawn" is performance-capture technique perfection, with the vividly real animal movements of the actors pairing perfectly with the detailed computer animation.  It is literally unbelievable - you would swear that these were real apes and, in a less competitive year, I truly believe that Andy Serkis would have been nominated for best actor.  The plot was a bit weak but serves as a good bridge between the ape escape at the end of "Rise" and the inevitable battle of the species (which we will hopefully see in the next film).  One of the biggest perspective-changing aspects of the film is the establishment that neither species are the good guys or bad guys.  By basing the conflict off of a misunderstanding, it is clear to see that they could coexist but have no choice in trying to eliminate the other.  The film sets a great tone with its opening.  I don't typically buy into the "global news report opening sequence," but this one is a perfect recap of the previous story and puts the global spreading of the ALZ-113 virus into perspective.  In spite of the special effects and grand-scheme-concepts that this film adds to the series, the human acting is a mess.  Gary Oldman was completely underutilized.  He is the biggest name in this film and the writers even acknowledged that by giving him an incredible emotional moment, but then his character basically disappeared and didn't get another "moment."  The same goes for Keri Russell, who isn't given a chance to use her acting chops, and the rest of the cast who just kind of exist to create a reasonable story.  I can't get over the fact that a ton of CGI apes have more personality than the live humans on-screen, but I mean that as a compliment to the apes more than an insult to the humans.  It feels like some of the script was hastily thrown together with repetitive scenes and a lack of intelligent dialogue.  When half of your movie is without dialogue due to ape interaction, you would think that the other half of the movie would be well-written.  Still, the incredible animation and apocalyptic San Francisco make those flaws hardly noticeable.  "Dawn of the Plant of the Apes" needs the rest of the series to make it a great movie, but its special effects would be worth watching even without a plot.

After the success of Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011), it's climax and epilogue screamed out for a sequel, and here it is. Directed by Matt Reeves, (Cloverfield (2008) and Let Me In (2010)), this is a strong sequel which is more down and dirty than the first film, which shows where this new franchise will be going and how it might connect up with the original film series. It's been 10 years since the events of Rise of the Planet of the Apes, and the ALZ-113 virus wiped out much of humanity, causing society to collapse. In San Francisco, a handful of survivors work together, but petrol is running out, and their only hope is to start up a hydroelectric dam, which will bring electricity to San Francisco, but the dam is in a community of apes, led by Caesar (Andy Serkis). A team of scientists, led by Malcolm (Jason Clarke) goes to negotiate with Caesar to work on the dam, even though Caesar doesn't trust humans. Caesar's second in command Koba (Toby Kebbell), doesn't trust the humans, and plans a mutiny. It's a very good sequel, and there's some brilliant action sequences throughout, even the motion capture is brilliantly convincing, and you'd never thought you'd engage with apes, but you do, and the way they communicate is absolutely brilliant. It sets the stage for what's to come, even though we know who wins.

With all the stale reboots Hollywood has done the Planet of the Apes films are not only surpassing expectations of a remake, but also setting the bar for special effects and CGI motion capture to come. Andy Serkis is as brilliant as ever, and the story is engaging and thought provoking.

I don't think anyone expected the Rise of the Planet of the Apes to be as good as it was, I certainly didn't. But 'Dawn' is so much better. It's a completely different movie than the first, so much darker as a virus has erased so much of the world's human population. The new ape world is oddy realistic which makes it all the more terrifying. The relationship between Caesar & Malcolm is one of the highlights. Andy Serkis continues to give brilliant performances and not be recognized for them, as he does once again with Caesar. The effects & action are also really good. Apes riding horses with guns is pretty scary &...entertaining.

"Dawn" revisits the age-old tale of how we treat those that we "think" are different from us. 
If Man was made in the image of God, then the Apes of "Dawn" emulate the Humans who have scarred and
maimed them in their (the humans) quest to develop a new drug. In fact, how the native Ape language came to be 
hand signs is revealed as being sourced from the Humans long ago. As "Dawn" unfolds we see a crazed example of balance in 
nature where every action has an equal an opposite reaction. An Ape family, which, in the beginning was
perfectly balanced and strong suddenly enters a state of collapse (as if it is switching position with the
left-over humans who, heretofore, were the ones living in a state of chaos). Like a strange brand of contagion
one group that had been in dire straits now celebrates newfound hope and the Apes begin to fall into disarray
as they begin a violent assault against the Humans that had wronged them 10 years earlier. In the end, "Dawn" 
represents a point in time where a race to coalesce good forces against evil will determine the fate of
all major life on Earth. Matt Reeves does a reasonable job of directing "Dawn" and 
while this film is aesthetically pleasing and always hints at anti-Darwinism, 
it underscores the inherent violence that permeates the human race and anything
that humans touch. The land of the apes is a lush, beautiful place where daily tasks 
are meant only to provide survival of the family and sustenance for the home. This 
environment is contrasted early on by the impoverished 
surroundings that the humans take up residence in. While the Simian population comes across
as intelligent, cohesive, and vibrant, the struggling human population finds itself on the
brink of extinction, functions chaotically, and reacts rather than acting rationally. This film immediately grips the viewer. The dire straits of the remaining population is 
immediately grasped. The Apes live in the heart of a land where humans are in search of 
resources that can save them, but murder has stepped in and created an immediate rift between
the two groups : so now the question is how the humans can take control without dying in the process, 
because the Apes do plan to kill them if they should ever trespass into their world again. Like a foolish teenager in a slasher horror flick, the humans are just too hard-headed to 
keep away. Venturing into the forbidden zone again, the Apes discover their trespass and 
hilarity ensues (if you want to call it that). The pain of the Apes' past dealings with humans (and the human fear of the Apes) is palpable 
but at the same time displays fright and amazement in single moment are apparent. The humans
realize that things don't always fit into a neat little box in life. After all, these Apes can 
talk. It's clear to see why the Apes want nothing to do with the presumptuous attitude of many 
of these left-over humans; and while the hope of viewers is that the goodwill can overcome the 
omnipresent ignorance of these left-overs, it seems almost certain that it won't. 
From the start the humans are always first to threaten, first to kill, and were the root of the 
plague that has nearly destroyed all of humanity and disfigured or killed many Apes. As dissension, mistrust, and human loathing start to tear at the very fabric of the Ape community, 
Caesar's control of his world becomes threatened. Infighting follows as frustations boil over. Still, amidst the factions that are fighting there are small relationships based on friendship and
caring that start to bud between some of the humans and Apes, underscoring the reality that
even in real life there are those who are good and those who are bad and that we have to be deliberate
in order to differentiate between the two. Some humans and Apes befriend each other. Other Apes covertly return murder in kind to their human
adversaries, and the question of which is truly the intelligent race is really never decided.
In the end we never really know who the savage is, who more brutal, or who is more inhumane . . . 
Us or them. It's a question that we already should know the answer to. This effort is as good as any other in the series of "Ape" remakes that I've seen.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is an action packed, pulse-pounding science fiction thriller that succeeds in being vastly superior to it's intense predecessor, Rise of the Planet of the Apes. Andy Serkis gives an incredibly unique and heartfelt performance as the film's fearless protagonist, proving once again that performance capture should be praised just as much as regular performances are, and should be considered for the Academy Awards. Dawn of the Planet of the Apes' visual effects are truly astounding, and one could even say they are some of the greatest effects ever put to screen, as without them the film wouldn't be nearly as good as it is. In a sentence, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is one of the best movie sequels ever made, as it is superior to its predecessor in every aspect.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes manages to up the ante in every way possible from it predecessor and then some. In acting, motion capture, cgi, story and themes, it just raises the bar from everything the first movie did, and does it better.  Andy Serkis is incredible, along with Toby Kebbell, both taking motion captured performances to the level where awards should be handed out for acting. The direction from Matt Reeves is terrific, especially the battle scene with the tank with the rotating top. He got the best out of both apes and humans, while capturing the scale of the city and forest habitats both to their utmost. All in all Dawn gives you everything you could ask for in a sequel, while furthers the story in a direction that set up an awesome third movie.

Fight for Caesar

The planet has been ravaged by a government created disease that kills 499 of every 500 humans it comes in contact with.  Meanwhile, the apes that escape the labs have formed their own home and community in the woods.  In the apocalyptic world, small pockets of human survive and need to use a damn to get electricity back in their facility, but they will have to gain the trust of the monkeys to accomplish their goals.

"Do they look like just apes to you?"

Matt Reeves, director of Cloverfield, Let Me In, The Paul Bearer, and episodes of the television series Felicity, delivers Dawn of Planet of the Apes.  The storyline for this picture was way better than I anticipated and is unpredictable and action packed.  The special effects were also perfect and this is the first one that compares to the original in terms of quality.  The acting is also very good and the cast includes Gary Oldman, Jason Clarke, Kerri Russell, and Andy Serkis. 

"Scars make you stronger."

Review:
Now that I've finally watched this movie, I must admit, it is brilliant but it does take a bit of time to get going. The apes look amazing and there face expressions and mannerisms were excellent but after hearing all of the hype, I was slightly disappointed with the whole pace of the film. I loved what the director done with Caesar's character and the relationships with the various apes and humans was interesting and a joy to watch. I couldn't help but thinking that the movie might have been better if the director would have got some top class actors to work alongside the apes, but thats just my honest opinion. Anyway, the whole humans against apes concept was well put together and I couldn't wait for the Caesar vs. Koba showdown, which didn't disappoint. Its definitely a must watch for all movie goers and I can't wait for the next instalment which has been built up to me a major blockbuster like this one. Great!

Round-Up:
Jason Clarke, who plays Caesar's human friend, has a unique style of acting which isn't for everyone's taste. He has a distant screen presence which can easily make you forget that he was in a film. He's starred in movies like The Great Gatsby, Lawless and White House Down but I doubt that anyone can remember him in those films. He's also got a role in the new Terminator Genisys movie so he's obviously a actor that's in popular demand at the moment. Personally, I would have cast Gary Oldman as the lead in this film because it could have done with some emotion and depth but judging by the movies takings, it didn't really matter who played the lead. Andy Serkis has become the puppet master when it comes to playing CGI characters. His amazing movements and mannerisms as Gollum and King Kong, really made those movies great and with the new Star Wars and Avengers in the pipeline, there's no turning back for this unique actor.

This sequel is less impressive than its predecessor. There's much events that can be predictable, much slow action sequences and the characters are mostly terrible.

The main issue I have with this movie is that there's no clear main character, the movie kept changing focus, and I guess that's the point but it feels stupid. There's also too much focus on the apes and too little on the humans, it's understandable but I want more focus on the humans. More on the characters: there's no chemistry between them and it feels dumb and awful. Another flaw is that I could predict almost every main plot detail in the movie, much more than in Rise of The Planet of The Apes. I also expected a greater soundtrack from Michael Giacchino, who gave us the awesome soundtrack in "Star Trek" (2009) and the TV-show "Fringe". The action is just as the soundtrack: less impressive and less unique. The movie does in fact have some great moments, it do raise even more ethical questions than the previous movie. It also does a great job when it comes to illustrate what no knowledge results into. The movie is also emotional powerful, and the CGI is spectacular. It's much clearer and detailed than in the previous movie. Not flawless though.

The opening scene is exiting and the first act is totally superior over the second and the third. They are predictable, slow and less entertaining. The ending however, could have played out much better. The previous movie was much about science; this however got a more basic tone about survival and coexistence. It's too boring for my taste.

Accomplished second part of the "Rise of the planet of the apes", it tell us the follow up of advanced chimpanzee Caesar. He has learned to talk and he has been teaching language to fellow apes, he is the leader of an ever growing community leaving in the forest surrounding San Francisco. In the meanwhile humankind has been decimated due to simian flu, the colony that barely survives in the city needs to get to the dam to produce energy; but the dam is in Caesar's land, when a group of men trespass they initiate a quarrel that threatens both species. 
The plot and the set up is carefully planned, it would have been easy to fall for clichés, instead we find a movie with a sensible story of trust and betrayal that strikes the right notes, in places it has echoes of plays of Shakespeare and at the end there is a good battle scene which is computer generated but that is believable enough to make us think in that possibility. A really good and entertaining film with good performances by humans and "monkeys".

God, making Caesar the center of this franchise was the best decision the filmmakers could've made. He's such a captivating presence throughout both movies, and this movie definitely does justice to the potential he showed in the first one. When Koba shot Caesar, I was so shocked, and I thought it was so ballsy of them to kill him off. When it was revealed he didn't actually die, I was slightly disappointed, but I was mostly glad, because the movie (and likely future installments) wouldn't be as interesting without him.

One of the most interesting parts of the movie is that for the first half and large portions of the second half, there isn't a specific good guy or bad guy. I mean, we're supposed to root for Caesar, but we're supposed to root for most of the human characters too (minus Carver). Koba is obviously the main villain, and the movie needs one, but in all the big battle scenes, you're torn about who to root for. Watching the humans kill the apes is painful, and it's equally painful to watch the apes killing humans. Everyone is innocent. All this senseless violence is thanks to one greedy, sociopathic ape (Koba), and he's the only truly evil character. But are all the other characters good guys, then, or is EVERYONE a little to blame? Gary Oldman's character, Dreyfus, certainly reacts rashly, and refuses to listen to Malcolm. Sure, Koba is mostly to blame. But so are the other apes for so blindly following him, and so are the humans for striking back without hesitating, fueled by preconceived notions that are seemingly being confirmed for them.

Also, the action and direction are just awesome. Though you can't really root for anyone in the all-out war in the second half, it's still fun to watch the great action sequences unfolding before your eyes. I particularly remember two great camera sequences: first, when Koba takes over a tank and the camera remains level on the tank as it spins and destroys everything it points at, and second, the tracking shot when Malcolm walks through a building, hiding to avoid the apes running around with weapons. The second one especially is extremely tense, the camera tight on Malcolm as he wanders through hallways where an ape could seemingly jump out at any time.

The earlier sequences, and the first half in general is a little boring, mostly because there isn't a ton of time to develop the severely thinly drawn human characters, but that's hard to avoid. Thankfully, even the earlier scenes are imbued with tension, because you just KNOW the ape-human relations are going to explode, but you don't know how it's going to happen. I kinda sympathize with the filmmakers, because it's a little hard to develop the characters beyond the specific purposes they serve without the movie being bloated. Jason Clarke is decent in the role, but he doesn't really have a personality, and Keri Russell's character is even worse off. There are a few tiny touches, like with Alexander's drawing and the nice little scene when Alexander and Ellie bond, but it's not enough to make them really compelling beyond being human archetypes to interact with the really interesting apes.

But those relatively boring scenes at least serve to make it more shocking when the violence really begins. It's clear that Koba is tricking the two men when he plays dumb and dances over to them, but it doesn't make it any less shocking when he suddenly grabs a gun, fools around for a second, then ruthlessly kills one man, stares the the other man in the eye for one spellbinding moment, then kills him, too. It's tense and disturbing, and though the movie isn't as constantly entertaining as a summer blockbuster like Edge of Tomorrow, it's emotional and thoughtful and exciting.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a wonderful movie that features great action, stunning visuals, and one of the best central characters in recent blockbusters. The story is interesting, with Caesar and his tribe of apes living peacefully in the forest. No humans have been seen for a couple of years, until one day they see one. Tensions rise, and eventually peace doesn't prevail. Emotionally stirring and with a hard look at human nature, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes rises above "Rise of the Planet of the Apes," and above most other summer blockbusters.

The story of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes isn't anything new, but the way it is told makes it feel fresh. The struggle for power between Caesar and Koba is captivating. There are even times that you forget that you're watching animated simians instead of the real thing. The human side of the plot is a bit weak, but overall this is a very well-made movie.

Starrring: Andy Serkis, Jason Clarke, Toby Kebbel, and Gary Oldman
Directed By: Matt Reeves
Written By: Mark Bomback, Rick Jaffa, and Amanda Silver
Rated: PG-13

10 years after the events of Rise of the Planet of the Apes, Caesar and the apes he freed have set up a home deep in the woods outside of San Francisco. They live in peace and raise their families. Until a small group of surviving humans, led by a man named Malcolm, stumble upon the ape's home in an effort to fix the nearby dam that will turn San Francisco's power back on. Can Malcolm and Caesar work together and keep the peace between their two groups, or will all out war erupt between them?

2011's Rise of the Planet of the Apes turned out to be a great surprise for me when I saw it in theaters. I went in assuming that they would mess up with the subject matter and it would result in a goofy movie. However they pulled if off and it turned out to be a fantastic movie with great acting from James Franco and Andy Serkis. This one wasn't ended up being not quite as good though and felt a little underwhelming. You should still see it though.

Every great thing you've heard about Andy Serkis' motion capture work is true. The man is phenomenal. Not once during the movie did I think, "that's a man behind all those movements". Of course the CGI helps, but if something doesn't move like it should, then all the CGI in the world won't help.
Of course Serkis wasn't the only motion capture actor to work on this. Toby Kebbel, Nick Thurston, Karin Konoval, and Judy Greer (yes that Judy Greer) all delivered great work and disappeared into their ape characters.
Lest we forget, there were human characters in this movie too. Gary Oldman is seen little unfortunately, but he does have some good scenes and touching moment when we find out whether or not the dam did what it was supposed to.
Jason Clarke does a decent job replacing James Franco as the lead. His presence isn't as memorable though and neither is his character for most of the first half of the film. Which is a problem almost all the human characters have. You really end up caring more about the apes anyway, so the fact the humans are kind of forgettable doesn't ruin the movie. A more solid human lead could have still helped the movie a bit more.
Fringe and The Walking Dead's Kirk Acevedo shows up too and he played a pretty good jerk and ends up being the most memorable.

To me this movie didn't really feel like the "Dawn" of anything. Some stuff happens, it gets resolved, and in the end it feels like not much has changed.
Don't get me wrong, I liked the movie. It just felt very much like filler to connect Rise to whatever the next one will be. 3D was pretty pointless as well so I would say pass on that.
Also I may have missed it, but when does Malcolm learn Caesar's name? Between when they first get chased off and when Malcolm returns, I swear none of the apes say call him by name so he had no way of knowing. Just something that bugged me a little. It still had some cool ape fight moments, top-notch CGI, and great ape characters. Some slightly more memorable human beings could have helped, but overall a decent follow-up. Fans of Rise will still want to see this one.

7 Reels Out of 10

Even so, as a post-appocolyptic vision that's not so post, it's interesting to see humanity struggling to return to normal and apes rising.  It's an interesting chapter in this strange story.  I'm amazed how what was essentially a b-movie concept managed to be taken so seriously.  There are moments of true emotional resonance in this film, as well as some spectacular action pieces.  Suffering from prequelitis, it left me a little let down at the end, but the ride there was good enough to forgive it.

This is a superior sequel to the reboot that, intelligently and wisely, brought what many had considered a dead franchise back to life.Â  The sequel expands the universe this franchise takes in.Â  While I really liked the previous movie, in my opinion, it lacked a little depth.Â  It was straightforward and somewhat one-dimensional thematically and emotionally.Â  I get the intention but, while very good, it lacked a little something that would've taken it past where it got.Â  Maybe it was the nature of it being more of an origin story, which isn't an excuse, and the fact that it needed to tell, but not show,Â  the beginning of how the world and humanity collapsed to the point where apes are the dominant species.Â  This film, truly focusing on the effects of, what they call, cleverly enough, the simian virus and how that disease has caused a certain unease between the humans and the apes.Â  The universe is definitely a lot more detailed and extensive.Â  There's a lot more depth to the supporting characters and to the apes themselves.Â  The apes have very distinctive personalities in spite of the fact of their lack of truly conventional dialogue.Â  While the film doesn't take a black and white look at its characters, I believe Gary Oldman's character thought he was doing what was right for his people, without a hint of malice.Â  But, Koba, the main antagonist of the film, doesn't have that same treatment.Â  I believe his intentions, at first, were to look out for the apes, but as the film progressed, he became like a regular villain.Â  That's not to say that the character isn't good, because he is, his motivations are just more cut and dried than other characters in the same film.Â  This is an ambitious film that opens up so many new possibilities and stories to tell that it's really exciting looking forward to what's next.Â  Of course, no review of this film would be complete without mentioning the fantastic motion capture work from all the actors who play some of the more prominent ape characters.Â  I don't think Andy Serkis, more known at this point for his motion capture work than his acting, ever truly gets enough credit for how talented he truly fucking is.Â  This guy is a great actor and he should get credit for truly making Ceasar come to life.Â  I don't wanna say there's a realism to the character, but there's a believability to Caesar's, and the rest of the apes, movements that is only achievable through motion capture.Â  And the actual animation of the apes is pretty outstanding as well.Â  It's really the best of both worlds.Â  You get the best from your actors and the best from special effects.Â  The film does have its action sequences, but they are, thankfully, not grating or loud.Â  They're there when they're needed, not because it's been 10 minutes without action.Â  That's the way it's supposed to be.Â  The acting is also quite good from the human side of things.Â  James Clarke and Gary Oldman, particularly the latter, are always great.Â  I just really liked this film.Â  It advances the universe forward in all the right places, actually leaving you wanting for more.Â  Greatly recommended film right here.

An explosive and thoughtful sequel anchored by two incredible motion-capture performances from Andy Serkis and Toby Kebbell.  Complex in theme, the film never takes the easy path and manages to make all characters sympathetic, even when you disagree with them.  Even the primary antagonist feels fully justified. You simply could not ask for more from a summer blockbuster.  If the APES franchise continues to treat its material with such high stakes care, we're all in for many more years of quality storytelling.

My last film of 2014 and it was a good one! Needless to say I vote for peace, trust and cooperation between the apes and humans because united we can co-exist beautifully. We have a large group of genetically evolved apes living in the ruins of San Francisco by the Muir woods. On the other side of the woods, at the guarded tower of the ruined city lives the small population of humans who are genetically immune to the deadly ALZ-113 virus which wiped nearly 90% of the human population. The humans need access to a hydroelectric dam located at the ape's territory, which could provide long-term power to the city. So they visit Caesar's territory to seek help in their quest and the story continues from there. Fantastic visual effects, story, direction, acting and emotional depth that will make you want to cheer for both species, especially Caesar and his gang. Humans help the apes in several instances and the apes return the favor as well. Overall solid, good film in Blu-ray, not to be missed! Happy New Year everybody!!

As I have said time and time before in my reviews I often either have huge expectations for a film or I have no opinion whatsoever and go with the flow. Dawn of the Planet of the Apes was another film I had very big expectations for. Growing up I remember the films being played via VHS over and over again by family members and the TV series we used to watch as well, so my love for talking human acting apes started a very long time ago and after seeing the prequel back in 2011 I have very much been waiting to see how the apes actually take over mankind.
Dawn of the Planet of the Apes did not disappoint me one little bit, from its opening scene's and beginnings where we learn that the human race is dying out due to what is known as the "simian flu." To the very last scenes I was on the edge of my seat, I was sucked so hard into this universe that I couldn't find one thing wrong with the film apart from a few slow scenes and a little CGI mishaps other than that I can honestly say I loved everything this movie gave.
The story takes off about 10yrs after the earlier prequel "Rise of the planet of the apes" as I stated earlier the human race is slowly being wiped out by a simian flu and now Caesar and the other apes he released from the science labs live in their own world in the middle of the forests. They have fire, they have school they even have written word but most beautiful of all is their use of sign language. It's amazing to see. Now I know it was all CGI at its finest but I could not help being sucked in t the gorgeousness and loving nature the apes had amongst themselves and the way they have grown. Down the way a bit a tribe of humans who are immune to the flu have formed an army to survive. What they need though is power and the only power source near them is in the middle of the Apes new homeland in the way of an old power dam. A pact of peace is proclaimed so that the humans can get the dam restored but of course there are always though who are against diplomatic solutions and do what they will to destroy any chance of peace being made on both sides.
I'll say it one more time in case you haven't heard me but I absolutely loved the movie, if you let yourself get taken away in its beauty this film will definitely please. There are so many things going on in the background and of course we can all say the movie is actually some kind of great metaphor for the battle we are facing currently whether it be our environmental war or even wars between nations but if you can ignore all that this film stands out on its own as its own battle.
Now in saying all that I actually went with my partner and whereas we usually agree on films we didn't on this, his first reaction was laughter and his second was the fact it was just so (as he put it) "hokey". He didn't enjoy the film at all in fact he found it laughable, he couldn't get over the apes behaving so human. What I found out afterwards though was that he never grew up with the apes as a child, he never seen the prequel so he had no expectations apart from my own which left him very let down.

Having only recently just watched this much hyped film, I think some of the praise it gets is slightly over the top. The film takes place ten years after the events  of Rise of the Planet of the Apes.

The cast of that film is missing presumably dead after the virus which turned the apes into smarter than average spreads across the world killing hundreds of thousands of people, only those naturally immune survive.

The action takes place in San Francisco and nearby woods, humans go into the woods looking for a dam which will supply much needed energy, unfortunately the apes lead by Ceasar (Andy Serkis) have actually created a home beside the dam. While Ceasar  is willing to let the humans do their work and be on their way his second in command Koba wants revenge and all out extinction of the human race for the way apes were treated in the past.

First things first this film looks amazing especially the apes and the characterisations of the apes, the use of sign language and some human speech is truly original. The humans who include Jason Clarke, Gary Oldman and Keri Russell unfortunately have very little characterisation outwith surviving and doing right by the people in the city. Though Oldman does have one brilliantly handled scene amidst cliched leader scenes.

Special mention goes to Andy Serkis who has created a truly original character to go along with his Gollum character from the Lord of the Rings, and it will be a shame if he is overlooked come awards season.

Drawbacks of this film include some ropey CGI effects, the sub-plot of koba starting a war between two species is very much in the style of Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country hence done before, though these are minor quibbles. 

Overall this is an entertaining film, very much an original take on the mythology with some drawbacks , though these drawbacks do not take away from the experience.

A war begins to brew between man and ape in this sequel to the 2011 hit Rise of the Planet of the Apes. It's been ten years since the Simian Flu wiped out most of humanity, and somewhere deep in the woods outside of San Francisco, Caesar (voice and performance capture by Andy Serkis) and his primate companions have established a thriving village built on the principles of peace and community. Shortly after welcoming a baby brother into the family, Caesar's son Blue Eyes (Nick Thurston) is walking through the forest with his friend Ash (Doc Shaw) when they cross paths with a human named Carver (Kirk Acevedo), who impulsively draws his gun and shoots Ash at the first sign of aggression. As it turns out, Carver is part of a human expedition led by Malcolm (Jason Clarke), who, along with the rest of his crew, races to Carver's side just as Caesar and the rest of the apes answer Blue Eyes' desperate call for help. An enraged Caesar drives the humans away after realizing they are no longer a threat, and decides to dispatch a small crew to follow them rather than yield to the pleas of his aggressive advisor Koba (Toby Kebbell) to launch an all-out attack. Instead, he decides to show the apes' strength by amassing outside of the humans' makeshift community at the base of an unfinished tower, making it unmistakably clear that the two species should remain apart. Meanwhile, the point of the human excursion was to get a dormant dam running again in order to power their community, which will soon be thrust into darkness should they fail to take action. Convinced that he could strike a truce with Caesar that would allow the humans to repair the dam, which is located on the apes' land, Malcolm gets permission from human leader Dreyfus (Gary Oldman) to set out on his mission. Incredibly, thanks to the help of his girlfriend Ellie (Keri Russell), his son Alexander (Kodi Smit-McPhee), and a few other key allies, Malcolm succeeds. Still, his truce with the apes is a fragile one, and just when it seems that the primates and humans have learned to coexist in peace, a shocking act of betrayal threatens to spark a war that will determine the dominant species.

With the successful 2011 reboot of the Apes franchise (following the dismal failure of Time Burton's 2001 attempt), you knew a sequel was coming. This time around, though, the movie is very different in both theme and setting. Rise was a techno-thriller commenting on society. This was more of a post-apocalyptic tribal film.

There is an opening montage that is a rehashed version of the closing credits for the previous film, and we are then confronted with the worlds ten years later. The apes now have a society, and Caesar is their leader. They soon encounter a group of human survivors, and there are many complex political machinations that ensue (reminiscent of the first Mission Impossible film).

The apes seem far more interesting than the humans here. While not exactly one-dimensional, the humans lack the interesting relationships established for the apes from the previous film. The shift in tone, while fresh, made the movie fit the mold of many human-survivalist movies, although I will give credit to the filmmakers for giving the apes the screen time they deserved.

While still an entertaining movie, it falls short of Rise.

With seamless visuals, sophisticated undertones, and an Oscar-worthy from both Andy Serkis and Toby Kebbell, this film improves on the already successful predecessor and cements the legitimacy and worth of the franchise revival.

It seems the apes have struck gold twice with Rise and now Dawn of the Planet of the Apes. 

Andy Serkis continues to separate himself as the best motion-capture actor of our time as his portrayal of Caesar.  But it's not only him this time. Koba has an expanded role as the villain while some of the other apes get singled out for bigger roles with the motion capture.

Unlike the first film where the humans really came off as the bad guys, the second time round we have more ambiguity as to who the heroes and villains really are.  It's almost as if you could watch an entire movie based purely on the apes style of living and rise from primitive culture to something humans might have survived in.  What's great is as the movie progresses, so does the apes understanding and evolution.

While Gary Oldman and Keri Russell add the star power in subdued supporting roles, Jason Clarke stands out as the lead human actor with compassion, smarts and reasoning to at least be the guy you root to succeed.  

The story really does have a war-like mentality about it.  You can see the chances at peace failing as underhanded tactics and backstabbing are put into play by the apes.  Both sides, apes and humans, are lumped into the same category.  It was a testament from director Matt Reeves to prove the two really aren't exclusive, but similar in more ways than you can imagine.

"Rise of the Planet of the Apes" was undoubtedly a decent film.  But if "Rise" was a decent film, then "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is the perfect sequel in every way.

It is evident from the opening scene of the apes hunting.  The action is better than the first film.  The cinematography is absolutely beautiful.  The drama and character development is also better than "Rise".  As amazingly human as the apes were in the first film, they are even more so this time.  "Dawn" deals with many real-world human issues and struggles like foreign relations, xenophobia, and war.  And of course, it goes without saying that the motion capture work is stunning.

To say that "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is a great film is an understatement.  Not only is it a great action and sci-fi flick, but it is also the first Planet of the Apes film since the original to be about something more than apes riding horses.

After Rise of the planet of the apes I knew I was bound to see any further installations to this series as Rise was a big surprise hit for me. Fast forward now to Dawn of the planet of the apes. I must say that the series is really moving in an impressive manner. Almost everything about this film is an improvement from the first, which is saying a lot. The story is a great and logical continuation from the first, the acting/cast is amazing on all parts but particularly in our returning protagonist, Caesar, played by Andy Serkis, who in my opinion is an extremely underrated actor and deserves an Oscar. The effects are absolutely unbelievably incredible this time around. There was one point where the camera zoomed in to Caesar's eyes almost in an eyeball to eyeball perspective and if I hadn't already known it was CGI, I would have had difficulty believing it was. The emotion throughout is well placed and  extremely effective, especially in the area of the interactions of the apes within the film. All in all I'd say this is easily one of the best films from 2014 and it's well worth adding to your home collection.

"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is seriously one of the most INTENSE movies I have seen! A drastic improvement over "Rise", which itself was a decent experiment gone generic. This is an emotional rollercoaster that left me on the edge of my seat, jaw dropped (not exaggerating here). It compellingly delivered a message that is relevant to us right now: there is good and evil in all species of the Earth and that we must overcome our own nature to be selfish and violent in order to do good for this world and eachother. While war is a part of our nature, we must still believe that there can be peace and that we must look beyond ourselves to find it. Great story, impressive visual effects, and convincing acting overcome some two-dimensional characters and slightly forced moments. That aside, it is the best movie I've seen this year so far. This is proof that summer blockbusters can be deep, compelling, and intellectually thrilling as they are viscerally.

Visually stunning, emotionally moving, and filled with thrilling action sequences, 'Dawn of The Planet of The Apes' is a smart blockbuster that succeeds in every aspect. It's yet another showcase for a fine performance by Andy Serkis, as well as for his co-star Toby Kebbell.
