Spoilers!!!
This movie has enough plot holes in it to drive a truck through. First off, there are a bunch of Apes by our dam! They don't kill us when we shoot one of them. They show up in force and say they don't want war but they'll fight if they have to. Why at that point would you persist with the dam idea? Everybody is dead, so there are probably other dams. Maybe a bunch of solar panels laying around? Other generators or fuel sources?

Nope. We have to go for the dam that has a bunch of dangerous apes around it. Also, if they already have fuel for cars and generators, why do they have to wait for the dam to work so they can start powering their radio transmitter. Power it off the Generators.

Second plot hole: They've survived for ten years. Wouldn't they have some kind of organization and administration in place to where they wouldn't all just start chaotically yelling and arguing to the point where their "leader" has to get a bull horn, and barely succeed in stopping a riot. Come on. These people have been living together and surviving for 10 years.

Third big plot hole. Why bring the crazy jerk dude with you on a peace keeping mission to fix the dam? Did he suddenly develop a brain tumor and was a real nice guy before, but now they're just realizing he's a reactionary idiot who's going to start a war?

Fourth big plot hole. The bad ape walks into the middle of the camp with all of the apes there, and shoots Ceaser in plain sight, and... nobody notices. Ahem.

Fifth big plot hole. The human camp is gearing up to attack the apes, but when an ape shows up in their perimeter they don't kill him, and in fact let him get close enough to disarm and kill them.

Sixth big plot hole. Hey, let's put our armory with all the guns not behind these big safe reinforced walls, but outside of our defensive complex, so they apes can go their first, arm up, and then attack us.

Seventh big plot hole. Ceaser has led them through thick and thin. When the apes realize he's alive and that the bad ape killed him, wouldn't any of them come to his defense?

Eighth big plot hole. The apes get guns and learn how to use them, and yet the guns seem to have 24 hrs. clips that just keep shooting for every shot. There is no real indication of them learning how to release a clip, load another, and then chamber a round before shooting again. Not only do you not see them ever reload, you never see them carry any ammo, through they fire on automatic continuously.

Outside of the many plot holes, the characters are never really well developed. There are plenty of slow moving parts in this film where you could have really gotten to know the humans and apes. I have a fairly good memory. I just watched this film, and I can't remember any of the humans names.

Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes is one of 2014's best movies and also acts as a marginal improvement over its predecessor. This film takes place after the events of its predecessor where Caesar and his Apes are now living in a peaceful life away from civilization. When a band of humans arrive and Caesar gives them a chance to fix the things that the humans need distrust and tension soon starts to rise between Caesar and his second in command Ape Koba and soon the Apes will lead a war against the human race which will determine who belongs to earth either the humans or Apes. I remember watching the premiere of this film with my parents in the cinema and I seriously enjoyed it a lot even though I watched it for the second time at home on my DVD it still blew me away and seriously this is one of 2014's best blockbuster movies to date and also the best in the Planet of The Apes series since its predecessor. Ok let's get on with the review. When I said that there are so many things on why I consider this to be a true masterpiece its because this film has all of the things that every blockbuster buff wants. One of the film's stand ups or highlights is that the film not only acts as a marginal improvement over its predecessor but also acts as an expansion to its predecessor and we get to focus on the perspective of the apes instead of the humans. In Rise Of The Planet Of The Apes the film is focused on the humans while in this film we get to see more of the apes from their point of view throughout the film and it gives the film a very smart feel. The other good things about this film is that the movie's pacing is outstanding the first half and second half focus on drama while the third half goes into action territory until the intense climax and it never gets boring at all. The other highlights of this film is that the movie has loads of scenes that are extremely memorable and well achieved(The opening scene, Koba killing two humans, Koba shooting Caesar, Apes attacking the city, Koba riding a tank, Caesar vs Koba and the intense scene where Koba kills Ash). Also the cinematography is ace and the editing is gobsmacking plus the soundtrack composed by Michael Giacchino(Mission Impossible III)is perfect and it gives the movie a strong emotional feel that is touching and very dramatic at the same time. Also the screenplay by Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver and Mark Bomback is amazing and I love how the film seriously surpass the original in many ways. The other highlights of the film is that the movie has loads of superb settings I love the woods where Caesar and the other apes stay along with the city that the apes destroyed. But the true main highlight of this film is the themes and tones along with the acting. I love how this movie keeps you interested from the beginning until the end and the themes about Humans and Apes are superb and it makes you think about whose side are you on and who will win I just adore it a lot. Also I love how how we get to hear Caesar talk more often compared to the first one and I love Koba's appearance as well and he gets to appear in every scene of the film. Now the acting is the second highlight of this. All of the casts did a very good job with their performances in the film. Gary Oldman did a superb job with his performance in the film as Dreyfuss. Jason Clarke did an outstanding job with his performance as the main character Malcolm while Andy Serkis and Toby Kebbell did an outstanding job with their performances in the film as Caesar and Koba. Director Matt Reeves did an outstanding job with his work on this film and he seriously created a stunning film that has a lot of action and drama. Overall Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes is a stunning and well achieve film from start to finish  and one of 2014;s best films ever made. This movie get a 10/10.

"How much like them we are"

10 years after the events of 'Rise of Planet of Apes' got over, the events of 'Dawn of Planet of Apes' follow. We saw that some virus originates causing an epidemic called simian flu spread across the globe during the closing credits of the previous installment. The same events are show in the opening credits of this one. Most of the humans on the earth's surface are wiped out and few who are alive seem to be somehow immune to the virus. While the apes lead by Caesar have established a new home in the forest and growing in population day by day. The group of human survivors need a dam to be back in operation so that they get electricity but the problem is it lies close to the ape territory. And there the differences on both sides start to begin.

Caesar played by Andy Serkis(motion-capture) is definitely my favorite character from both Rise and Dawn. His character is well written and Andy Serkis has done a marvelous job. Despite knowing nature of Humans he still is sure not every human is bad. While in the other camp of humans, people are panicking as the apes are smarter than ever and feel threatened. Gary Oldman isn't at his best but does his job. But its Jason Clarke as Malcolm who is more likable. The bond between Malcolm and Caesar that slowly and strongly develops is one of the strongest points in the film. Also other positive includes, the tension that builds up on each side on the slightest doubt against each other.The CGI and motion capture is also top notch. The post-apocalyptic environment is quite haunting and effects on apes are damn good. Its doesn't not look perfectly realistic but still one of the best works in recent times. 

The weak point of the film is it gets quite predictable and towards the end turns into routine action flick filled explosions and more CGI. Also some plot advancements might not make much sense,but its bearable. The ultimate point of film in my opinion is that no one perfect on either side, which is the main cause of misunderstanding. Humans are always feel threatened when they see something far advanced while apes are afraid of humans destroying their species like they destroyed earth. One point where Caesar says "I always think ape better than human. I see now, how much like them we are.", kept me thinking about our nature for quite some time.

Dawn is way different movie compared to Rise. So if you liked the first one because it featured a playful pet-ape Caesar than don't expect same thing here. But still despite its flaws Dawn of the Planet of Apes is strong movie with good intellectual and emotional depth. Only if they did not make it feel like a blockbuster action flick in the second half it would have been pretty much better

RATING: [3.5/5]

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes was certainly engaging, and all-in-all, entertaining. However, there are notable flaws with the film particularly surrounding the script.

As was the case with its predecessor, there is the attempt to evoke emotion through the use of personifying monkeys and apes. As with the first film, there are points in the film (as there were in the first) in which I would find myself groaning out loud, with the director trying to play the 'look at the cute animal and become attached to them' card. Entwined with were some unoriginal underlying themes which felt mashed together to churn out the final product. Combine this with the dystopia in which the movie is set, and the film felt like it was the lion king meets lord of the flies meets 1984. Originality is by no means the hallmark of a good script. However, for me the script was just so obviously unoriginal and shallow, and in attempting to be profound and intellectual, it enhanced the script's weaknesses.

Despite the lack of depth in the story, the CGI is outstanding. It is an easy watch, and not engaging in the mechanics of the script too much should provide for a couple of hours of entertainment.

I was always a fan of the old series, but now I am even greater fan of the new one. This science fiction film directed by Matt Reeves and written by Mark Bomback, Rick Jaffa and Amanda Silver, has everything the old movies were lacking! Especially the feel of reality. Starring Andy Serkis, Jason Clarke, Gary Oldman, Keri Russell, Toby Kebbell, and Kodi Smit-McPhee, this is the sequel to the 2011 film Rise of the Planet of the Apes, which began 20th Century Fox's reboot of the original Planet of the Apes . Visual effects are extraordinary, story smooth and flowing, direction mostly very good, acting of the humans was average, "apes" were amazing, and touchy feelings and emotional depth comes as a package. A lot of people agree with me, knowing that the movie grossed over $707 million worldwide.

There is no wonder that after the release of Rise of the Planet of the Apes, director Rupert Wyatt commented on possible sequels: "I think we're ending with certain questions, which is quite exciting. To me, I can think of all sorts of sequels to this film, but this is just the beginning." I think that is a perfect idea, and screenwriter and producer Rick Jaffa also stated that Rise featured several clues as to future sequels: "I hope that we're building a platform for future films. We're trying to plant a lot of the seeds for a lot of the things you are talking about in terms of the different apes and so forth." Really looking forward for it.

If you want to see  a very good science fiction movie, to be involved in the story, while not missing on emotional charge and action sequences, find some time to watch this!

Wow. There have been several times that I loved the first film in a series, waited a few years for the sequel, disliked, and then forgot about it. This is not the case.

This movie really avoids a lot of clichés. A few inevitable ones pop up, but it is really quite unique. The acting on the "human" side is decent. The characters are not incredibly developed, but they don't have to be. They have enough development and are not annoying. You care about their situation. Gary Oldman has a surprisingly small role, but a pretty good one. But the real star is obviously the apes. Andy Serkis and the team of motion capture actors are mesmerizing. The effects are great.

The movie also has a lot to say about the human condition. I won't ruin that.

The movie also had a lot of moments that really made me care and it was quite unpredictable

"Apes Strong Together"

A commendable and thrilling sequel to the first part. The series continues to be intelligent, and develops intriguing conflicts between certain lead characters. Through the screenplay is stronger in this one, it fails to deliver the emotional impact the first part did.

The CGI effects still never fails to amaze me; the precision to detail is incredible. Actors like Andy Serkis (Caesar) and Toby Kebbell (Koba) are commendable in their ape characters. Other supporting actors like Jason Clarke and Gary Oldman are commendable in their roles.

The character developments are predictable, but intriguing. There are a few plot-holes regarding the humans' stay in city and apes' armed fight scenes, but they can be ignored. Overall, the movie is spectacular and enjoyable.
Extremely overrated. Very dramatic with unnecessary pauses throughout. Ending was extremely dramatic just for the sake of it. Don't bother unless you have watched others in the series.

As a sci-fi fan this movie was one of those must-see movies for me. I have to say that I was not having the highest of expectations on it though and I also have to say that my expectations was more or less met. To me this is a mildly entertaining movie but it is certainly not a great movie.

The special effects with the apes are very good indeed. The apes look very much real and I was surprised at how much emotions that the special effects people managed to get into their facial expressions. The human actors also did a quite good job...within the limitations of the script of course.

However, the previous movie felt reasonably new, fresh and original (although it was fairly predictable) while this movie just feels like a rehash of some fairly standard, thirteen on a dozen, post-apocalyptic story with some apes thrown in to make it stand out. I really do not understand why so many people seems to think so highly of this movie. It is the all too common catalogue of stupid behaviors and sadly enough the apes seems to have inherited plenty of stupid behaviors from the humans.

It starts of with the usual scared-trigger-happy-idiot-shoots someone. In this case an ape of course. How many times have that boring excuse for kick starting the story been used? Then it pretty much goes on. The only mildly intelligent people in the town seems to be the Malcolm and Dreyfus. The two morons wasting ammunition on firing at a old car and drinking Whisky as well as the original idiot who tried to hide a gun deserved to be shot.

The only somewhat intelligent part was when the captured apes turned over a bus and took a bunch of their adversaries with them. The movie was indeed very predictable. The only thing that elevated the movie above the level of downright boring was the fact that half of the characters were apes and, luckily as I wrote, those special effects were very well done.

The blurb from Twentieth Century Fox states that "...both sides are brought to the brink of a war that will determine who will emerge as Earth's dominant species.". Well yes I guess that you cannot say that this is a downright lie but it is definitely a bunch of hyperbole to sell the movie. Come on, we are talking about a very limited group of apes, badly decimated as well, against the rest of the surviving humanity, which obviously have some modern facilities left and a war that is more or less just assumed will happen.

A mildly entertaining movie but certainly not a great movie.
Waste of time trying to rediscover the original...
Although not horrible, I wouldn't want to ever watch it again.

Yes it seems to be official, Gary Oldman is apparently in everything!. Much like the ALZ-113 virus he gets into everything and...errr kills it? no wait, analogy misfire here.

Following on from the first reboot of this classic franchise with this new cracking title we now see the results of simian flu as its wipes out most of humanity across the globe. Only pockets of people who are naturally immune to the disease are left to try and rebuild whatever they can from their former existence as the dominant species on Earth. In the mean time Caesar and his ape companions have evolved further living in a big Ewok village just outside San Francisco, they don't want war but will fight if they have too.

Right first things first...holy piles of elephant dung this movie looks good! and when I say good I mean sumptuous. The first shot is a close up of Caesar's glaring eyes as his pack stalk prey on the hunt. To say this image is haunting is an understatement, you'd think it was an actual person! in fact I don't even know if it was CGI! (probably was). This first sequence sets up the rest of the movie clearly showing you the effects have been pumped up vastly (they're on steroids) and we are now easily on terms with Kubrick's space odyssey. That's not to say director Reeves doesn't know this...oh he knows and he takes full advantage with some very familiar sound bites that hark back to the beginning of man in that little space flick. You can hear the same type of choir usage in the opening sequences and in the end with heavy orchestral beats hammering it home just in case you're a bit mutton. Yes its not exactly original or very subtle but it certainly sounds epic and works well. As the apes swing through the thick mist swept trees and foliage bearing down on their kill you can't help but be mightily impressed. The whole thing looks and sounds like something that should be from Arthur C. Clarke's seminal sci-fi novels if adapted now...its almost too good looking for this silly franchise.

This is not the only epic shot or sequence within the movie, the emotions expressed by Caesar and various other ape characters is pretty darn amazing. People are saying Serkis should get an Oscar for his performance but admittedly I really don't know where he ends and the CGI blokes take over. The general movement of the mammals is very very good but lets be honest here, there are many dancers and performers that could probably do that. What really impresses is the CGI work on the fur, wet fur especially and everyday movements  and emotions in the ape faces. There are times when you think you're watching a real chimpanzee it looks so good, Koba especially looks very realistic with his mottled skin. The large orangutan is another highly realistic looking creation as are the gorillas. Some chimp characters are more obvious than others strangely, mainly the lead characters like Blue Eyes don't look as good, the female apes aren't as good either, Caesar on the other hand looks the most human (I guess that makes sense). Is it me or does Caesar actually look like a bearded Charlton Heston in this flick??!

Not only do the apes look good the locations and sets look tremendous too! The ruined San Francisco looked...real! it genuinely looked like they trashed the place for the movie. Its within Frisco that most of the big action takes place too and again I can't deny it looks very grown up and very real. This is most definitely not your average summer blockbuster affair for the scroats oh no, this is a proper science fiction tale with gritty visuals. Is there anything more terrifying than seeing a bigass rampaging crazy chimpanzee upon a charging horse wielding a big assault rifle?? Let me rephrase that, is there anything more terrifying than seeing a crazy bigass chimpanzee upon a charging horse wielding a big assault rifle...and it knows how to shoot the thing quite accurately!!! Especially when the chimp in question is Koba who lets be honest...is a scary looking motherfucker. Oh...where did they get all the horses??

On one hand the battle sequences are viscerally exciting and pretty brutal with lots of grand slow motion shots of certain apes looking both macho and intimidating. On the other hand I couldn't help but feel uneasy at the entire thing, here I am watching all kinds of apes getting blown to shit and mown down by automatic gun fire as if it were 'Saving Private Ryan'...but with apes. Should I be enjoying this? I felt sorry for the apes and didn't really enjoy watching them die like humans...I know how that sounds but animals are different to us in movies, don't like to see them killed. I guess feeling sorry for the apes was the idea as most had been forced and tricked into a grisly war. 

It did make me chuckle a little bit at the start though, the humans in Frisco could of easily wiped out all the apes in a matter of minutes seeing as they were all tooled up, game over. The apes only had spears at the time, plus the main lead human character could of spoken to Caesar right there and then instead of encouraging trouble by disobeying the apes line in the sand ultimatum. Why didn't they ask the apes about the dam right at the start when they had the face-off, perfect time, instead he goes off later into their village pissing them off even more. I also must ask how many apes there actually were! I know in the first movie many escaped from the zoo and test facility but Jesus there are apparently hundreds upon hundreds of them! Most get killed in the Frisco siege yet there are still tonnes of em', a literal army of apes, did seem a bit implausible even with ten years of breeding.

Lets not get ahead of ourselves though, this isn't a cheap action flick with cheap moments of gun totting cheese...OK there are one or two moments of convenient cheese, but not much. On the whole this movie delivers in depth levels of powerful human qualities such as leadership diplomacy acceptance wisdom authority loyalty and honour...with CGI monkeys. The gamut of emotions we see Caesar dealing with against the humans from anger and spite, to realisation of his own kind and finally acceptance that his apes are not better than humans after all is incredibly poignant. Of course on the flip side we see all the negative aspects of the human race played out via Koba.

It does all seem very much like a science fiction movie...which it is, but when you look into ape (chimp) behaviour its actually quite an eye opener to see that they can be quite vicious to one another. Some of the facial expressions you see displayed by Koba are very accurate which is pretty daunting. I will admit I didn't totally enjoy the very end as it seemed too much of a weak acceptance by the apes for pending war, I'm sure the remaining humans could easily speak up for them seeing as what happened was only confined to a small area. I did enjoy the fact there weren't any cliched baddie human characters for once but unfortunately Reeves seemingly couldn't resist an over the top setting for the final battle.

End of the day this does feel a bit like yet more filler or padding for the real focus of the franchise which is all out war between humans and apes. I do kinda feel they could of gotten to that point already instead of stretching it over two movies. But truth be told this is a rip-roaring science fiction adventure that not only betters the original by a good country mile, it also manages to be one of the best science fiction movies to come along for some time (yes its even better than all this comicbook fluff).

This is by far the best and most entertaining movie that I have seen in a long time! Everything about this film is just dripping with intrigue, especially the opening sequence that shows the apes way of life and how they have adapted to living! To me it was truly remarkable and I would recommend this film to just about about anyone! The acting especially behind the mask of Caesar is beyond riveting. The human characters all pale in comparison.

It's been four years since "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" director Matt Reeves last cinematic outing, "Let Me In" - an English-language remake of Swedish director Tomas Alfredson's vampiric coming-of-age film. While there will always be film aficionados who insist the original take of a film presents its truest form, I felt Reeves' reboot wrought a more kinetic, more universal telling of the tale and that Reeves had created an instant classic of the horror genre. My respect for "Let Me In" was immense.

Over the decades, Reeves has paid his dues in Hollywood and his career has veered from comedy ("The Pallbearer," an early and soon-to-be infrequent outing by "Friends" star David Schwimmer) to helming one of the first features to bring the now largely defunct "shaky-cam" (thank goodness) effect to big screen - his clever, if Dramamine-required, alien-invasion film "Cloverfield." Capable of delivering both drama with sensitivity and visceral shock, Reeves seemed an excellent choice for this latest installment of the "Planet of the Apes" saga.

Unfortunately the material he's been given to work with isn't of the same quality as Alfredson's wholly original horror concept or enough of a pure action-fest like "Cloverfield" to let one overlook the general mundanity of "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes'" story. How possibly mundane can a planet of talking apes be? Aside from the fact that these simians have now been performing their grunt-speak to audiences for over fifty years (Maurice Evans' buttery, upper-class mannerisms notwithstanding - what planet was he from?), that novelty remains fairly fresh.

But it's "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes'" screenplay that comes across as flimsy as Linda Harrison-as-Nova's" deliciously hung rags. If one were to take away the apes as players (which would be a waste as they are miraculously rendered CGI creations), stripped of tooth and fang, "Apes" would be left with an all-too-human and all-too-cliched story.

The film revolves around the "stop the madness" efforts of a good-hearted human survivor of the simian-virus apocalypse and the now imperially seated Ceasar of 2012's "Rise of the Planet of the Apes." These two suffer fools, villains and rebellious children as they toil haplessly to bring peace to opposite ends of an inter-species battlefield. The CGI action is exciting, but the behind-the-scenes powerplays of their shared struggle - however novel on the Darwin spectrum - feels too familiarly packaged.

The screenplay, credited to Mark Bomback, Rick Jaffa and Amanda Sliver, makes the writers sound less like science fiction visionaries than a preachy team behind a Vietnam-era anti-war film. There's a decidedly "retro" feel to the futuristic war film, with the camouflage-clad ghosts of Audie Murphy and Dennis Hopper lingering somewhere just out of sight.

The story trudges along dredging up far too many plot points from Shakespearean-aspired royal dramas; I'd recite the litany of cliches but I don't want to spoiler-ize anyone's fun. Gary Olman, who once shone in the sun as a lean, English mad dog, now seems comfortably settled into playing roles of the flustered heavy (and I still think he applies the same touch to his American accent.) He's ostensibly the leader of one of the last tribes of humans, but his nervous fidgeting makes it difficult to believe he would be put in charge of much more than a AA meeting.

The cast of largely unknown actors doesn't help either. Though capable, they never bring any real fire to the screen, although lead Jason Clarke works tirelessly at his angst. Unfortunately, the human cast is frequently emotionally upstaged by computer-generated apes, that in itself a scary accomplishment which may, indeed, portend the fall of mankind.  Or at least the Actor Guild of America. On the other hand, I never know exactly what praise to lavish on human-marionette, actor Andy Serkis. Certainly dancing around in leotards glued with styrofoam balls for the roving eye of a computer to map can't be easy, but the question is how deep does one's Stanislavsky have to run?

But the film's real problem is its script, and its by-the-numbers roll call of devices. Without the apes, I imagine the plethora of well-intentioned, but tired war movie cliches would have "Apes" garnering far less praise than it is receiving. And those hokey-ending lines gravely spoken by the defeated peace-makers ... Where have I heard them before? "I thought we had a chance," says Clarke. "So did I, my friend...so did I," intones the moribund chimp. It's almost a pity that all the battling that has come before falls into a pile with those oh-so heavy lines, which ring as outdated as a throw-away bit of hippy schtick from "Easy Rider."

Of course, the action fans may not notice these overwrought grarnishes, as they have been rewarded earlier to a fiery finale of two foes battling it out, swinging on an exploding skyscraper, as the inevitable flames lick at their feet, er, paws. While "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" will certainly please the action crowd with the most technologically advanced simian set pieces yet, it's ultimately a pretty routine and not terribly clever affair. Invoking the film's catchphrase, "Ape not kill Ape," I would proffer, "Ape not make Sequel." Though I'm sure "the heavies" will triumph again, man.

The sequel to Rise now sees the world's human population decimated by Simian flu, while intelligent apes roam the wilderness. Caesar (Andy Serkis) grudgingly accepts to aid a human colony living in the ruins of San Francisco restore their electricity, but encounters opposition from xenophobes on both sides intent on starting a war. The story is compelling because it is strongly allegorical of a myriad of conflicts the world has seen, and still sees.  Most remarkably, however, the film comes to life thanks to the brilliant motion captured ape performances (here Serkis does an outstanding job as Caesar, but so does Toby Kebell as enemy ape Koba) while the top notch CG effects makes them look virtually photorealistic.

The movie achieves what an ideal wholesome entertainment film could ever achieve but with a cast of motion captured actors portraying Great Apes. There is a smooth balance of drama, emotional content and terrific action sequences. There exists a archetypical villain, a righteous leader, the conflicted son, a flourishing and prosperous society and then there are the humans who are nearing extinction. The premise is ripe for conflict and promises an exciting conclusion.

The movie has high ambitions and this is made clear early onwards when it begins with a terrific hunting sequence of the apes and the introduction of Caesar, the protagonist Ape from the previous film. He has remained the leader and now commands a legion of Apes as his followers with whose help he has built a flourishing Ape society who are remarkable learned to read and write within a span of ten years. The setup is incredible for a film and yet so simple in execution with no exaggeration so as to make this seemingly impossible scenario less believable but instead it is totally acceptable to our logic. 

The conflict arises when it comes in contact with a group of surviving humans, whose first action is to shoot an ape in presumed self-defense. The actors give a convincing performance but they are consisting of the stereotypical variety for a survival flick: the skeptic, the optimist, the pragmatist and then there are the rest of the expendable cast who are not given any significance and rightly so. The human and the ape leads are the emotional centre of the film when they explore the feelings of community, future, peace and most conspicuously trust, which is simultaneously in loads between the two protagonists but lacking between the rest of their kind.

The film contains special effects like the opening sequence involving a hunting scene, the standoff between the humans and the apes near the colony entrance, the final climatic duel and explosions all in a grand destructive aesthetic to create awe. The most important aspect of the film perhaps is the motion capture and how Apish and Human the CGI Apes feel - we empathize with them whole-heartedly while anticipating their evolution into the flawed human-like being that is their inevitable destiny. 

For a reboot of a classic sci-fi franchise, this exceeds anyone's expectations and delivers a consistent balance between emotional overtones, intelligent narrative and destructive potential that many summer blockbusters all in lack holistically. There is definitely scope for another one with the same exciting caliber.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes surpasses all of my expectations and is even better than its amazing predecessor Rise of the planet of the Apes. Dawn is the perfect summer blockbuster with a great story, intense action, and amazing performances. Andy Serkis gives an incredible performance as Caesar putting as much heart and character into him as possible. But for every yang there is a yin and in this movie the yin is Koba. Koba is an awesome character and a great villain who steals the show in almost every scene he's in and shows that apes and humans aren't as different as they seem. Dawn also gives messages about equality, understanding, and working together without forcing the messages down our throats. If your a fan of Planet of the Apes or just a fan of great movies in general than you should definitely see this movie.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is an excellent film. It is aboutapes who have survived a pandemic disease ten years ago are drawn into battle with a group of human survivors. Andy Serkis, Keri Russell, and Gary Oldman give amazing performances. The screenplay is well written. Matt Reeves did a great job directing this movie. I enjoyed watching this motion picture because of the action and adventure plus drama. Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a must see.

"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" begins where the closing credits to "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" ends - watching a graphic of criss-crossing planes carry a new plague around the world. With a little exposition we learn how most of the world drops dead of "simian flu." There are a few survivors, huddled together in cities, unaware if they are the last ones out there. We meet a group out of San Francisco, led by Malcolm (Jason Clarke), a good and noble individual, and Dreyfus (Gary Oldman), another good man who just wants his people to be safe, but is perhaps a little more willing to let the ends justify the means.

From the film's opening close-up on Caesar's eyes to the final frames of the story, the apes are front and center, and WETA Digital has pushed performance into a whole new realm with the work they do here. It's one thing to pull off one or two characters like this, but to lean as heavily as they do here on the digital team to bring to life dozens of characters, and to have them all register as fully as they do here, is a remarkable accomplishment. Add to that the idea that so much of this was shot outside, on real locations, and you end up with something that destroys any boundaries in terms of what can or can't be done at this point.

The script by Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver, and Mark Bomback is about what violence does to communities, so while it is indeed an action film at times, and there are some thrillingly staged sequences that director Matt Reeves has imagined, I found myself actively rooting against any action in the film simply because I cared about all the characters enough that I didn't want to see any of them, human or ape, end up in harm's way, and it's obvious from early in the film that things are not going to end well. Once a human community, led by Dreyfus (Gary Oldman) and Malcolm (Jason Clarke) comes into contact with Caesar's apes, tragedy seems inevitable, and it's awful to watch it unfold.

What an exciting and thrilling blockbuster! I was worried about this film. This was the 8th add on to the Planet of the Apes series, second to the reboots. So this Is a sequel and an eighth movie. I expected that it would feel a bit stretching, but it isn't. In fact, Dawn of The Planet of The Apes' main purpose Is to show another side of these super apes and to set up the story for the next film in the franchise. 

This isn't just about fighting; in fact, fighting scenes, even though they are epic, take very little part of the film. There is romance within humans and apes families, sometimes, the apes can act funny. Dawn of The Planet of The Apes is thrilling and kept me at the edge of my seat the entire time! Also it has a story line no one expects! 

The original Planet of the Apes book is about humans that went to a planet ruled by apes. When they come back to Earth, the same thing happened to our planet. The reboots, (Dawn of The Planet of The Apes and Rise of the Planet of the Apes) are pretty much prequels. So, Caesar leaves civilization with his ape friends while the human race almost goes extinct due to a deadly virus. The remaining humans struggle for power. Will they be able to find a new source of power or will it be up to the apes and their leader to decide the humans' fate?  

For me, this is a fantastic addition to the series. They don't try too hard to make it too action-packed and cool looking. The apes look extremely realistic and I really like that. They include some scenes from Rise of the Planet of the Apes which helps to pull it all together nicely. The action and fighting even has some stuff from the original 1963 Planet of the Apes book! The director made it a perfect length and, in fact, this is the first time I've seen what I would call a "trailer" movie (a movie that looks like an hour-long trailer for the next one in the series) that is entertaining and includes a surprise ending. 

My favorite scene is when we see a small group of humans working on the power station. When they wake up, the youngest is sitting with an ape that acts as a teacher to young apes and is very loyal to Caesar. The kid gives him a book and reads along with him. It shows how well they actually understand each other and how alike humans and apes are. It shows friendship and how two creatures of different species can be friends. 
This film has some violence and intensity so I recommend it for ages 12 to 18. I also give it 5 out of 5 stars for fantastic graphics, a well planned story, excellent cinematography and stupendous acting. 

Reviewed by Gerry O. KIDS FIRST! Film Critic. For more youth reviews, go to kidsfirst dot org.

After the surprise hit reboot of the "Planet of the Apes", it is needless to say that expectations were high for the sequel. Did it deliver? Yes.....on every level. Andy Serkis leads the crew as ape Caeser, who attempts to prevent all-out war between humans and apes, while human Malcolm, portrayed by Jason Clarke, does the same on the other side. The CGI in this movie is the highlight, making everything look incredibly realistic. Rather than using just pure effects from a computer, the director has opted to use motion-capture with his actors to make everything look all the more realistic. For the main ape role, Andy Serkis, the king of motion-capture (tell me Gollum was not amazing), is the perfect choice and makes the movement and actions of his animal character look unbelievably real. It's not just Serkis though and new addition to the cast Toby Kebbell, who plays angry ape Koba, who has had a bad experience with humans unlike Caeser, rivals Serkis in how realistic the actions can be made to look. The use of motion-capture really adds to the film. When you see Koba riding a horse and jumping through fire, it looks like a real ape riding a horse and jumping thrgh fire. The humans fare just as well, being portrayed as equally sympathetic characters rather than people who just wish to kill the apes, as parallels are drawn between the humans and apes. Jason Clarke's Malcolm acts as the Caeser of the humans, wishing only to protect his family from the horrors of war while Gary Oldman's Dreyfus parallels Koba, wishing to eliminate the other side ultimately to protect his people and believing that apes are just animals. The tone of the movie is very dark and gritty, showing the difficulties of living in a post-apocalyptic world. One of the best examples of this is when Dreyfus charges a battered iPad and sees a picture of his dead family. You really empathise with the character here and realise that he is not just a villain, creating a strong emotional moment. The soundtrack is also excellent, adding to the dark atmosphere and amplifying the emotional as well as action-packed moments. One of the most interesting things the movie opts to do is have no speaking for the first 20 minutes or so of the film, giving a really interesting insight into the culture of the apes and how they live. My only gripe with the movie is how much the ending sets up part three and does not tell a full story. Don't get me wrong, I am very excited for the next one but it sets it up so obviously at the same time. In the end, however, "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is still an excellent film with an amazing cast (especially Andy Serkis and Toby Kebbell for their incredible motion-capture work) and amazing effects and atmosphere and makes extremely excited to see what the next installment in the franchise will bring.

Are you willing to watch an action packed movie that involves gun wielding apes, that also rides horses versus a small group of human survivors ready to reclaim the world that was lost to them.
As the movie beings Caesar (Andy Serkis) and his clan are trying to build a peaceful community, while Malcom (Jason Clarke) and other humans are trying to gather supplies and find a way to get things back to normal. That peaceful time is broken when Caesar's and Malcolm's groups collide in the woods and it leaves an ape wounded by a gun shot. Even though Caesar and Malcom both want to keep the peace, a rising tide of anger and mistrust between members in both clans (humans- Dreyfus(Gary Oldman) and Apes- Koba(Toby Kebbell)) result in all-out war. Just with the beginning part of the movie you can see a relationship form between Malcom and Caesar even though they may clash with each other they ultimately want the same thing and that is to protect, build up, and enlighten their communities peacefully.
In the website on Plugged In it says "Caesar repeatedly stresses that the only way to find a fulfilling and happy future is to turn from conflict and focus on building a family and a loving home-something he strives to do with his own mate and two little ones. That sentiment is reinforced when Caesar finds an old video of his deceased human friend Will who embraces him as a young ape and welcomes him into his home."

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes certainly lives up to the expectations set by Rise of the Planet of the Apes, but is a completely different movie in many ways.

Dawn has far better special effects than Rise, and is a lot more action centered. Also it focuses more strongly on human characters, leaving the apes with much less personality than in Rise.

This movie jumps WAY into the future as well. The simian virus (which was only touched on in Rise) has killed most people in the world, and Caeser now has a small army of genetically evolved apes. This creates a completely different story and environment, and instead of focusing on the struggle of the apes it focuses mainly on the struggle of the surviving humans.

Personally I prefer Rise to Dawn, but that's just my opinion. They are both fantastic movies.

A treat for the eyes, a story to compel and a main actor to mesmerize, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes has everything necessary to be one of the most intelligent and emotionally challenging summer blockbuster for years. In a rare exemption of the fact that sequels are less thrilling than original movies, the second installment further builds up on the moral issues raised by its predecessor and adds up a much engaging action to the story.

Ten years after the killer virus almost erased humanity from planet Earth, small groups of survivals are trying to re-build the human society, while apes are slowly evolving and building their own civilization. When both societies confront distrust and tension escalate within the masses. With two main characters from both species trying to build bridges between humans and apes, the story is a smart and challenging entertainment whose emotional complexity is stunning (given the fact that it is considered a summer blockbuster). 

Huge part of the emotional value of Matt Reeves' delivery is provided by the character of Ceaser, brilliantly played by Andy Serkis.  A leader, a husband and a father of civilization, he is no different than some great men part of the human history. Andy Serkis' ability to mesmerize with his facial performances, with his morally look of the eyes and his overall central presence on the screen are no surprise to those who remember him from Lord of The Rings. This time, however, he has to depict a leader, a leader that has a vision going beyond the understanding of ordinary people and apes. His terrific performance makes him almost human and compensates for the fact that his counter partner Jason Clarke is no match for James Franco's performances in the first movie.

In conclusion, Dawn of The Planet of The Apes is a must see summer blockbuster. Not for its visual effects and action sequences, but for its story, emotional load and unforgettable performance by Andy Serkis. After this delivery and the first movie the bar for the third one coming in 2016 is raised almost to an impossible to reach level. We have to wait and to hope that it would be matched.

I didn't care much for "Rise of the Planet of the Apes."  At the time when I saw it, I was definitely much snobbier about my movie taste but after revisiting it, I still could not quite bring myself to enjoy it all that much, but had a greater appreciation for it.  Origin stories aren't always the thing for me.  Sometimes I actually prefer a sequel, we already know all the characters, and the protagonist is already the fully formed character, we don't need to spend the first hour watching them become who they really are.
 
In "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes," Caesar is already a highly intelligent ape, we don't need to spend the first half of the movie watching him become that, we can get right into the action.  I always have trouble with the premise of "Planet of the Apes," I know there's lots of smart apes, but there's way more smart humans with weapons... just shoot the apes!  That's why the final scene of "Rise" doesn't work for me; watching apes take down a human army is absolutely insane to me... JUST SHOOT THEM, don't let them get near you, shoot them before they get there.  Done.  Movie over.  So because of all that, I did not expect to buy into whatever the plot of this new installment was, but I was delighted that instead of a world domination or takeover movie, they went with the classic "Pilgrims & Indians" plotline from movies like "Pocahontas" and "Avatar."  The humans want peace with the Apes, so they send over some people to make peace and everything is working out just fine but due to some misunderstandings, the hot-headed generals decide to ignite war.  Classic plotline; it never gets old, people will always be drawn into a story like this because it teases you with peace and then frustrates you with the inevitable war that will happen near the end that could be avoided if there was better communication.
 
I remember when "Rise" came out and everyone was screaming for Andy Serkis to get an Oscar nomination for his motion capture performance as Caesar, the leader of the apes and scoffed at the thought, but now I can't help but agree that if the pool of Best Actor candidates isn't so great this year, why not throw him in?  I'll tell you why not, the Academy would never tarnish their snobby name by nominating an animated monkey from a summer blockbuster for Best Actor (prove me wrong, Academy).  Caesar is infinitely more interesting and complex as a character now that he is grown up and acts as a cautious but never vengeful leader of the apes.  Sometimes his gruff slow-talk can get to you but that is honestly the only complaint I have about his performance.  He is commanding, respectable and when he stands on two legs with his chest puffed out, you know you would do whatever he asked of you unless you want your head torn clean off.
 
The humans are actually the characters that aren't given much to do.  Jason Clarke gets to be the main peacekeeper and delivers the best work possible but in a role like this, his potential is limited.  I believe we will see a great role akin to what he did in "Zero Dark Thirty" someday soon, because he has the chops, no doubt.  Keri Russell is great actress, so it's too bad that she really doesn't get to do anything more than just be the unit's pretty doctor and Clarke's love interest.
 
I was worried about the Gary Oldman character going into this movie.  I know Oldman loves playing the villain, and wants to get back to doing that after playing good guys in the "Dark Knight" and "Harry Potter" films, but my worries were calmed upon meeting his character.  He is not the hot-headed general that just wants to kill the apes because he can, like Stephen Lang in "Avatar," but rather a worried human leader who is backed into a corner when Apes come knocking on his door.  We probably get the most depth from Oldman's character, we learn about the pain brought upon him by the Apes' virus, how he lost his wife and children; there's a great moment where is able to look at old photos of them on an iPad when power is finally restored to the humans' refuge and he breaks down in tears.
 
For a big summer action movie, this works as a bit of a slow burn.  There really isn't a big action setpiece until the final act but there is so much tension throughout, that I did not really mind.  I was on the edge of my seat watching the political structure of the apes' society be tampered with.  And kudos to the animation designers on this movie, because the creature design is so distinct.  You never get confused about which ape you are looking at on the screen because they are all just unique enough to tell apart.
 
"Dawn" really was the most surprisingly good movie of the year for me, at least so far.  The story is pretty worn and cliché but it still worked fine and there are two characters that I haven't mentioned that also fall into that frustrating cliché category as well but this movie really works and did a great job at expanding the world of this franchise.  I don't know if the next installment can top this one.  It really was a tight blockbuster.p

Does anybody remember the two-cruise-ships-with-bombs scene from The Dark Knight?  That scene is actually a re-enactment of an old micro economic problem, "Prisoner Dilemma".  The short story of it is, are you willing to make a small sacrifice with a potential adversary, and BOTH make good gains, or risk losing everything to win more in a fight?

Well, the amazing thing with "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes", is that the first three quarters of the movie is an amazing re-enactment of that problem.  Can we coexist and both prosper with someone you could be a potential enemy, rather than risk all out war where we could lose everything?

The modern day parallels are obviously there, from Israel to ISIL, to South Sudan, or even modern day challenges in multicultural nations.  Can communication, respect, and understanding be our standard, rather than war and destruction?  Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes provides a forum for discussion...

I've never been that big of a fan of Planet of the Apes. I've always found it weird and kind of silly. But in 2011, Rupert Wyatt made a film called Rise of The Planet of The Apes. I loved the film it was really well done , with a very hard hitting story about retaliation and freedom. Now in 2014 we've gotten the sequel , Dawn of The Planet of the Apes. Now with having new director Matt Reeves , I didn't know what to think because I loved the first film and what Rupert did with the apes. But when the movie came out of course I had to see it. Dawn of The Planet of The Apes out does Rise of The Planet Of The Apes by a long shot. Instead of telling a story of retaliation and freedom. This is more of the battle for survival. 10 years after of the events of Rise of the Apes. Most of the human race has been wiped out , and the apes have made there own civilization and are living in peace. Until one day a human named Malcom  (Jason Clarke) gets in the way of the apes and just wants there people to be in peace with the apes. This film , like I said is really well done. Andy Serkis gives one of the best visual performances i've seen ever since Gollum from Lord of the Rings , and he was Gollum. Caeser is one of the most well developed and one of the most interesting characters I've ever seen in the movie. Daw of the Apes did what transformers should've done. It makes the apes the main characters , not the humans , you come here to see the apes and what there doing. Theres not a lot of action in this film but when the action goes down. It really goes down. (APES RIDING ON HORSES). The human cast is really good as well. Jason Clarke gives a great performance , as does Gary Oldman. But the real scene stealer is an ape named Koba , played by Toby Kebell. He was the villain of the movie , but he was a lot more than that. Just like Caeser he has his reason of why he hates humans. I am really glad to say that this is one of the best films i've seen this year. It's either this or X-men.

One of the most comprehensive and compassionate examinations ever put on film of the causes and effects and events leading up to war. Current events parallels abound--the war on terror, of course, and also Ferguson--but this is pretty timeless stuff (or at least 20th-century-and-beyond timeless). Distrust, othering, admirable but dangerous allegiances to tribes and families and races, need for resources, access to arms. Ideals are compromised by the compromising situation. It's powerful, potent, even profound stuff, and it's masterfully executed. An extraordinary script, moody direction, beautiful, appropriately overcast photography, a score from Michael Giachinno that feels like distant thunder rolling in. Seeing this level of moviemaking is rare. Seeing this kind of operatic ambition in a summer blockbuster is rarer. This is a movie that is deliberate and grand, explosive and atmospheric, political and personal, over-the-top and contemplative. It's an action movie that relies on character and ideas, that has the audacity to make its audience read subtitles while apes sign to each other. It's another amazing installment in what may be my favorite franchise--a compelling genre movie that is smarter and more socially conscious than probably almost anything we'll see during awards season.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes Review
	Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a sequel to Rise of the Planet of the Apes. This takes place years after Rise and by now Caesar and the rest of the apes have established a civilization. Humans are almost gone and the few humans left want access to a dam so that they can continue to have power. However, there are tensions between both the humans and the apes especially with Koba as he wants an all out war between the two species. 
Pros: 
	This movie is visually stunning. The apes look like real apes and not just cgi. 
	The movie is well directed. There are scenes where there is really nothing going on but the person watching the movie can feel the intensity and it almost seems like you are in the movie. 
	The movie is not predictable like most movies. 
	The acting is great. 
	One does not have to watch Rise to understand this movie. Meaning that this movie can stand-alone. 
	The movie has a deeper message than just what you see. I see many historical references and I also see the concept of racism exist in this film. 
Cons: 
	It takes a huge time jump from Rise and it would have been nice if it connected better with Rise and offered a bit more explanation of what happened after Rise especially with a few characters. This however does not lower my score at all as it feels very minor when I watched it. 
Conclusion
	Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is an extremely great movie, which was well acted, well directed, and well written. It is a must watch for all movie fans. I highly recommend watching this in theaters as the intensity just jumps, however I can see this also being a great experience on Blu-Ray as well.

When 'Rise of the Planet of the Apes' arrived in theaters three years ago, it was met with great critical and commercial success.  It was smart, had clever direction at the hands of relative newcomer Rupert Wyatt, and was exciting enough to appeal to the summer movie crowd.  A sequel was inevitable - as Hollywood just can't help but go the route of the sequel anymore.  However, when Wyatt decided not to return to the director's chair, attention turned to Matt Reeves (Let Me In), an up and coming director with some nerd credibility.  Anticipation built, and the first previews started showing up promising action galore.  But would this just be more of the same from the first one, rehashing themes with new characters?  Or would this be an epic follow-up on the level of some of the great sequels of our time?  

Ten years after the viral outbreak, Caesar (Andy Serkis, 'The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey') has taken his serum-enhanced followers into the forests of northern California, where they have built a peaceful society.  When a remnant of humans shows up in their territory, calamity soon follows.  However, a human named Malcolm (Jason Clarke, 'White House Down') convinces Caesar to give them a chance to restore power to the survivors via a hydroelectric dam in the apes' territory.  Anxious to trust humans despite his kinds' mistreatment at their hands a decade earlier, Caesar allows it.  However, while power is being restored, a zealous ape named Koba (Toby Kebbell, 'The East') has plans of his own.  Soon a showdown between the apes and humans seems inevitable, even though Caesar and Malcolm both work to avoid it.   

Let's just get this out in the open - there are some major plot holes with this flick.  The spoiler-free ones include the apes' ability to utilize firearms with precision with absolutely no background training (which fortunately didn't turn into an anti-gun tirade) and the ability to repair a hydroelectric dam that has been dormant for a decade in mere hours.  That's really the tip of the iceberg.  One could pontificate on the development of ape society, but it would be a circular argument that focuses too heavily on the serum from the first film and evolution of society.  Now, these aren't the odious plot holes that permeate flicks like 'Green Lantern' or even 'X-Men Origins: Wolverine', but it's kind of disappointing given the amount of goodwill exhibited with the first flick (even though it had a few minor plot holes as well).  Plus, the marketing of the movie was kind of deceiving.  It presents this film as action packed, but this film is a slow burn and when the action finally heats up, it almost seems a little too late.  Necessary, but a bit frustrating.  

While the first movie featured few memorable performances aside from James Franco, this film seemed to step up a little in that category.  Clarke, Keri Russell (August Rush), and Kodi Smitt-McPhee (ParaNorman) make for a fine human side to the story, but the multifaceted Gary Oldman (Lawless) is all but wasted here.  The real draw once again is the performance capture roles.  Serkis once again proves that a performance can be truly wonderful, even when an actor is never seen in the flesh on screen.  He commands the screen as Caesar once again, and Kebbell is decidedly vile as Koba.  Their movements were clearly well-studied, and the wizards at Weta Digital have once again made the apes so incredibly lifelike that their work deserves due credit.  Also, it's nice to see the care that has been taken with the cinematography in this film.  Cinematographer Michael Seresin (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban) avoids the use of the shaky camera technique and really gives the film a great feel.  And composer Michael Giacchino (Star Trek Into Darkness) has crafted a score that is quite apposite in this film.  

Critics and those who were able to see it early compared this film to 'The Empire Strikes Back'.  They were sorely mistaken.  While this film certainly has emotionality to it and really utilizes the slow burn effect, it never really feels like it has anything compelling to offer.  It never really ups the stakes, and almost feels more like merely a setup for part three.  Maybe having the third part will complete this part much the way 'The Bourne Ultimatum' completed the storyline of 'The Bourne Supremacy'.  But despite Reeves' confident direction, this film feels more like an achievement in special effects than an achievement in storytelling.  It's nice that they didn't take this in a truly cliché direction the way many had feared, making Caesar a revolutionary type.  But it never seems to elevate him to more than a commanding presence with a heart for peace.  It'll be interesting to see where the series goes from here, but hopefully it's in a more crowd-pleasing direction.

If it stays true to its roots, this new 'Planet of the Apes' franchise will eventually evolve into traditional science fiction. In the meantime, director Matt Reeves presents a simple and tragically beautiful dichotomy: humans turning into animals while animals turn into humans. 

The reason it doesn't earn the sci-fi tag yet is because the chaos, shortsightedness, and cruelty that rips civilization apart in the movie feels uncomfortably close to our actual front doors.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is not only an improvement to the pretty darn good predecessor, but also one of the best movies of this summer mainly because of one thing: Its simplicity.
Let's begin by pointing out the absolute beauty of the film. With top-notch special effects, the apes look better than ever, and the post-apocalyptic world is terrificly designed and executed. Lush vegetation and slum towns take our eyes to a journey that was never achieved before in cinema. Visually is very striking, but as we get into the plot, we find even more.
With the world decimated by the lethal virus from the last movie, now the humans and the apes are trying real hard to live together. Both sides hate each other, and both sides love each other. They are societies that can't somehow fit together. As the tension grows between this two species, shit happens (No spoilers) and war breaks out, and Dawn of the Planet of the Apes shows its splendour.
The action scenes are exciting, but there is also a very powerful drama about the past of these characters, that make for some really moving scenes. Andy Serkis is amazing as Caesar, and of course that the humans aren't as interesting as the apes but their war is a sure grabber for audiences. I am only dissapointed that the very final scene feels very "middle chapter", because the rest of the movie is as good as it will get until now for this revitalized franchise.

After watching Rise of the Apes I really had high expectations for Dawn of the Apes. It did not let me down at all. I thought this was even better than Rise of the Apes mainly because Dawn of the Apes had more of a darker and more grizzly than the first one. It had lots of intense and heartwarming scenes that were really really touching. So if you're a planet of the apes fan you should go see this one, it was one heck of a ride.

The reboot was successful because of the way Rupert Wyatt "got it" and made us engage in the end of a species, as another one rises. The sequel is no more than a standard Hollywood sequel, that doesn't take that thought forward. It is just a spectacle of brilliant SFX and motion capture, without any of the story or soul that made Rise such a delight. Disappointed that they would let the original director leave and bring this guy in for the 3rd in the series. I guess like the 1968 trilogy, Apes is doomed to have the first film standalone from substandard sequels. Criminal waste of Gary Oldman didn't help.... That said, the film received an ovation at the theatre I was in, so it probably struck a chord somewhere. Just didn't plumb the potential of the story they started in Rise...!

The first installment of this Planet of the Apes (remake) series was, for me, a five star film. It had everything you want in a cinema film; emotion, action, humour, storyline and a trace of realism that made me want to watch it again so that I could understand the particulars better. This film was almost on the same level, except that it perhaps went slightly over the top in certain areas where action overwhelmed the proceedings a bit too excessively. Other than those specific moments I think that, if you can accept the science behind the apes' intelligence, you will highly enjoy the film at the cinema and, moreover, will probably want to watch it again when it comes out on DVD/Netflix/Amazon Instant.

The film takes place 10  years after "Rise of the Planet of the Apes"; the Supposed cure for Alzheimer's, which improves an apes brain capacity, has spread to both apes and humans in the form of a virus which wipes out most of the human race. As a surviving human community exhausts their last fuel supply they seek an alternative source of power in the form of a dam, the two sides meet and are forced into war by the actions of a few loose cannons. It does not choose to answer any questions the audience may have about the missing 10 years, such as 'what happened to the astronauts?' because the answer is obvious, likewise, it does not choose to engage in complex subplots and does not diverge from it's core narrative which allows for better characterization.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is unique among blockbusters in that it has inner beauty. The apes are brought to life with awe-inspiring CGI, coupled with exceptional motion-capture and voice acting, the English language is clearly very difficult to reproduce with an ape's vocal chords, you can hear the stress and harshness of every word, signing is preferred by the apes which produces long absences in dialogue that contribute to the film's gritty and earthly tone. Dawn of the Planet of the Apes does not compromise for action and visual effects; the film is superbly written and emotionally impacting. The movie acts more like a bridge for a sequel to document the evolution of a new "Planet of the Apes", but it successfully pulls you into their world and easily merits its own existence.

Boy, Andy Serkis has certainly carved out an interesting career for himself hasn't he? If you ask the general movie goer (who sees mostly big budget blockbuster films) and you ask them who Serkis is, they might actually know, but not use his actual name but rather just Gollum. Gollum being the role that brought Serkis fame throughout all of the Lord of the Rings/Hobbit films.

Now the interesting thing about Serkis is that most of his motion capture roles are universally praised by both critics and fans alike. Many will even say that some of them are Oscar worthy even. However, the Oscar nomination never comes and we are left to recognize Serkis' talent on our own (which at the end of the day is probably more important). As you can probably tell by these first two paragraphs, I am a big fan of Mr. Serkis and he has delivered yet again in his second go as the mighty Ape leader, Caesar in Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.

The film begins and ends with us staring into the cold and threatening eyes of Caesar, neither time can we differentiate those eyes from that of an ape or human. Serkis' use of his eyes are what makes his portrayal of Caesar as good as it is. He is able to express so much emotion through them and say exactly what his computerized ape-like body is thinking and we feel that. We are able to see the anger and frustration that Apes have with humans based on past experiences. We are also able to see Caesars' nagging sense that not all humans are bad also based on his past experiences being raised by a "good man" and the inner conflict he is wrestling with throughout the film over how to balance his loyalty and trust between both apes and humans.

What are we to take from this film? Are we as humans not as developed and advanced as we think we are? We witness two intelligent species that claim the other is flawed and really a sub-species compared to themselves, but we watch as both sides make the same mistakes that will eventually lead to the potential downfall of either one. Perhaps we have not developed as a species much since we evolved from apes all of those years ago but the film also shows that we have that capability for progress. It also shows how capable we are for complete self-destruction based on our tendency to turn on each other in time of chaos. When conflict arises, we too often turn on one another so that we can survive instead of working with one another collectively to solve a problem. Now you think I'm gonna try solve that crisis? Please....I've got Breaking Bad to re-watch on the 'Flix.

After the pleasant surprise that was the first film of the new Planet of the Apes series, the expectations for the sequel, or middle part of the trilogy, were somewhat bigger. Thankfully, everyone involved was fully aware of that and delivered another smart blockbuster with a lot of vital commentary on the futility of war and violent conflicts. The film doesn't want you to pick a side too easily as hostility between the last remaining humans on Earth and the intelligent apes arise. There are decent and bad characters on both sides. This makes for an interesting ride, as the conflict spins more and more into chaos and there is little anyone can do against it, after a point of no return. Once again, the CGI is incredible, thanks to great motion capture acting and the accompanying special effects. Thankfully, the human actors are en par, especially Gary Oldman only takes two short scenes to make a strong point for being one of the best of his generation. The gloomy atmosphere, the great cinematography, it all adds up to an intelligent and pretty damn entertaining continuation of the story. If there is one complaint it would have to be that the ending is merely a cliffhanger for what's next in part three. But at least we all have something to look forward to.

The summer movie season is saved with another thoughtful and terrific film. Taking place directly after Rise of the Planet of the Apes, the film sees the United States wiped out by the plague seen in the first film. The apes have formed their own colony in a forest, while only a few humans are still alive. A group of humans in California are attempting to bring power back to their community, which causes a few humans to unexpectedly encounter the apes.

This film is on the same level as the first: a well-developed film, though it is also a little better. Andy Serkis, the king of motion capture, returns as Caesar, who has now formed a colony of apes, where he acts as their leader. Serkis, as well as the other actors depicting apes, is fantastic. You actually believe that you are watching an actual ape. Jason Clarke, Keri Russell and Gary Oldman wonderfully support the film. Oldman's character is an interesting one, since he's neither a hero or a villain. He's simply fighting for something that he believes in, while he's trying to protect those he cares about: the surviving humans.

Matt Reeves, who takes over from Rupert Wyatt, brings a different scope to the film, making it grittier and darker, which perfectly adds to the film's tone.

The film slowly weaves into the original Planet of the Apes, while it proves that summer films can still rely on interesting characters and a great story, not just stupid characters, repetitive computer generated effects and dumb story. Job well done.

Post apocalyptic simian sci-fi sequel in this follow up to the surprise hit prequel that saw Caesar the chimp and his monkey mates gain high intelligence whilst the same virus inadvertently caused a worldwide pandemic, killing most of the human population. The story quickly recaps the last 8 years as the apes now have a wooded fortress and an uneasy truce with survivors in neighbouring San Francisco but their need to fix a dam to provide energy for the immune humans begins a struggle between the two factions. An uneasy truce is upended by Caesar's second in command, the scheming Kobo, who wants revenge for his perceived mistreatment and sets about tricking the humans into a violent conflict. The CGI is simply phenomenal and certain shots have a photo realistic quality unseen in many other films and with the legendary Andy Serkis (Caesar) and the impressive Toby Kebbell (Koba) at their performance capture best, the film balances a fine line of spectacular set pieces, proficient plotting and sombre storytelling. The humans play second fiddle but Jason Clarke is great as the "good man" Malcolm, whilst Gary Oldman is his usual gifted self as a paranoid and emotional military leader. From the private to the primate, "Apes" continues the hefty issues raised by its predecessor and the audience will continue to enjoy the profound topics that affect the planet. 8/10 Midlands Movies Mike

@Dawn of the Planet of the Apes: Art Director Approved. This is the sequel to "Rise of the Planet of the Apes". You don't need to see the first one to appreciate this one. Both films are prequels to 1968's "Planet of the Apes".
Although I didn't go ape-shit for this film, I found myself mesmerized by the performance from CGI motion capture and visual effect. Absolutely believable. This evolutionary leap makes the original look like a puppet show. There is brilliance in simplicity: how the apes communicate to each other through rudimentary sign language and their thought process.
The plot had Shakespearean themes: family conflict, loyalty, betrayal. All leading up to a climatic conclusion. I felt more sympathy for the apes than the humans. That's true cinematic magic. It raises the question of who's the real animal.
Darwin was right when he said we are decedents from apes. Humans share 98% DNA with our hairy ancestors. I wished the film made a definitive proclamation of this scientific fact, but I suppose Hollywood didn't want to ruffle any feathers with its religious audience. The film is science fiction, after all.
